The black bar in the left-hand panel has a length of 1\u2003arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408807/mnras0422-3574-f4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408807\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f4.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=Z0E-dF9XJ8E01J1-xu5Uu6GRnNwyMn9AH4TP2y7lNflRplZYyTOznTcIouVvmjYLFvbo3LtBx6zTHNETfID3bQQN4TI8utUJh2xVcq-XkQQ0ThvUGa9nzUh3LeCr9dyvWreLr6ndtHQkanR698CX8GpzB0iPwVjeCwAcGgOQqAaseFofFdWvh4W2U5pSeAYy2RnfdPEKRgKcUvBmtA0TXcPSTl-eHDiMgTMFWzjewY4PNATGjq9yrY7iKtTwk6SE053ny-ECB72MK~A6yt7Xv4MEoem8adCv393K78WeUbjPGgovAQ8RAT-zp-JIT2TyJjru5Nkvu~~Pz42HkSAOXg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408807&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Images and gravitational lens models of SWELLS systems. Left to right: image, lens-subtracted image, lens model-predicted image (for a model chosen at random from the posterior distribution) and residuals of lens model fit. The black bar in the left-hand panel has a length of 1\u2003arcsec.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92408813 id=\"92408813\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2>3.2\u2002Gravitational lens model</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We fit SIE lens models with external shear to the lensed features of each system. The source plane position (<em>x</em><sub>s</sub>, <em>y</em><sub>s</sub>) and the image plane position (<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>) of a ray are related by<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m1\" content-id=\"m1\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><a class=\"jumplink-placeholder\"  id=\"mnras0422-3574-m1.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-m1.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=3znuW7gC~3G5hhsdjqRgz7Jpp7bANO5Kgqapp0ZeT6Df6XYc4Fi6g-Iw66a~8N0jyBtpYRBUZ0U5dEkyZ7niEG~Hky~DIhUp6ZrWmeJ0FQb4YAjmQMj5aKmo8SYxYV6LIGSS4PabqO1sqKlulXMwmKrtIIt63AN2-mFleDIkdc3JHNXFYCUMBFb7xJMN31xISxNGbXQgFfxdSqYB3QkLTIhZLplLToVbpsNwcbNg~yQBt8-4fy7GZMyxkEoUij3-w7owJtBv9PT-hoFauHfQ0Tn8vn-tZ8FOrupSjQARJGOu2MaeXdtmCaqnORNggoX8gQRpl30lHOxU2QVZSajp9g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-m1.gif\" /></a></div></div><span class=\"label\">1</span></div> where the deflection angles \u03b1<sub><em>x</em>, <em>y</em></sub> are given by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Keeton &amp; Kochanek (1998)</a>. Defining <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu1.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=SMgRqPOnDcJeJsJtFYFUTUHJJPtTQILNb-dkkgJh5BJgzHAebPM9AmZpu~HnOWg-MEnf236yEcjfAvDMlcqWjI6C7nELpbdYyXvQXcOOreK37tQ8o5mVVvgA0yxjiwqH6ocDiNnBf7tmGb8dHWl9udp-jpjA0FjPHy2bwF-D36F~qGohzj5v-meQae3DJ-tfSuh7l27E3ScJ0tpLngzu5wVdpbWC2oLFfDHqK678n~ki4ArO5La5z8ZvcC7x3Pnfd9WpTa5E-YyrqSSLY8~13fc6bqnijch1tMnzAGk6N-o8tmF1eq0hwFSFk2dcTVI8xeV6wqn24DgaTyX3q-~Wrw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu1.gif\" />\u2060</span>, where <em>q</em> is the axis ratio/flattening of the projected mass profile, the deflection angle formulae for the SIE component (i.e. before adding the external shear) are the following:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m2\" content-id=\"m2\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><a class=\"jumplink-placeholder\"  id=\"mnras0422-3574-m2.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-m2.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=Ql8DzL5byikQgiW7e5JGdkla8Lz4lSoeYZJrH3NYT19uFqZZ~4ZHdEa7p33evq3XUrgVAH7I4vlIizWi46gFJdcm5Dmr~1pwm-83iRbn1XJ4StOJ-~ZBul6mRX3y00y53e0RDib7jnttxr4JgBsfPrDsBnJPkjFODTwwp8xMt38Qtg1PKRVHVGB7k27~51yWwuXxTctZ~2V-vglHZGICOMPyIhS8ar4EJkX49YEPPqTmkorDsVDXnAx3YYHNGagP4vsFjeZSn9ZTS~HEExiQugEQojP7ekm-jIZge5FcNz0tryEsZH2L5kbCKoBEqm87ugtbckVYs1lxgKYoQWMJ2Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-m2.gif\" /></a></div></div><span class=\"label\">2</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m3\" content-id=\"m3\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><a class=\"jumplink-placeholder\"  id=\"mnras0422-3574-m3.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-m3.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=glGSrgodg1nilMY7GOpCmoUpaI0BpNcG-6Uf2GG2jEfESo76SaXsw7h8qQrPo0HvY4aJGhL08E0SMxAvKMHJjRXaNbhHGIr1odcVXHt9O9dx72T9IlDA28F3cnzCVIV06CDevmEiKGo8~XwRCFMPoyzqy2BGsImfHvS4jyrrE-MKKTdV22o-tdb2Yea~GDk1t1KQbfLqr2wuJOvlV97Sll9Gq8~80bRciQZnpKLb-xKNi9ZQJCu~KPZRXTjaVnGkMMPqSNjO9wt~SJ9Dq9sSI6bWWAyOoLiAuaMXl-t9CoETC5fHJJzE061zQJq4UuEG5Ak4ns-diGH6oaJmI5cF5w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-m3.gif\" /></a></div></div><span class=\"label\">3</span></div> as long as <em>q</em> &lt; 1. If <em>q</em> &gt; 1, then <em>q</em> can simply be replaced by <em>q</em><sup>\u22121</sup> and the orientation angle \u03b8 rotated by 90\u00b0, with the same result. We do not allow <em>q</em>= 1, but it can become arbitrarily close to 1 and therefore close-to-spherical lenses are not ruled out. The parameter <em>b</em> denotes the Einstein radius of the lens, using the intermediate-axis convention.</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In many cases, we are attempting to fit this lens model to image data that do not contain very much information. Therefore, informative priors on the lens model parameters are required. The centre of the lens model is fixed to be within \u00b13\u2003pixels of the peak pixel of the light distribution. The position angle of the lens model is assigned an informative prior, stating that the position angle of the lens is likely to be within \u00b110\u00b0 of the position angle of the lens galaxy light. The modelling results in an (intermediate axis) Einstein radius <em>b</em> and an ellipticity parameter <em>q</em> for each system. Once the lens model parameters have been estimated, the Einstein radius in radians can be converted to an equivalent velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub>SIE</sub> using<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m4\" content-id=\"m4\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><a class=\"jumplink-placeholder\"  id=\"mnras0422-3574-m4.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-m4.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=2S3rZqzDvmW3BSRDp95mwivs7usLP53qccevBPtafPcRrTneX18O02WnsAX0Q8LIQqNJlGsuZhJuh9xMmYUKmyclnsEZkVIXw~jch7X73-Phn7vzZZQEP97b50iekAxPpVo-876AZrKcutEha~WH-Lr-3TRnzjwpEFEmlU~uPuz6VgY0HcMlhznhSJ3-yN6wVH3kcEs7tblEs4kxbxKjEiYReCRNOmFrhxAX1VK65EM1oCCt1tea1icSCby0YYBYlWJGYczHHVq~-TJ4DZm0So7iEEtqsBxr0vvVCq-z2UvAHqf4koII4cdOYF9O2fQcH7WpZxavPH8litoYnxIYIA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-m4.gif\" /></a></div></div><span class=\"label\">4</span></div> where <em>D</em><sub>s</sub> and <em>D</em><sub>ds</sub> are the angular diameter distances (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b34\" data-open=\"b34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hogg 1999</a>) from the observer to the source and the deflector to the source, respectively. For simplicity, we modelled the sources with a single circular Gaussian component as this is adequate to explain the observed lensing configuration in most cases. For those cases where this model was inadequate, the source was generalized to be either an elliptical Gaussian (e.g. for J0820+4847) or multiple spherical Gaussians (e.g. for J0822+1828). Due to the presence of systematics in the data from incomplete subtraction of lens galaxy light, and also the simplicity of the model used, we do not literally perform the inference with the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b15\" data-open=\"b15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brewer et al. (2011a)</a> likelihood <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu2.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=2lTsPy4xRW1RjXr8iUB7j3CiR4tzaERMax6GlIjtzXeuGI252s-yfDTvj0uYroEPdfMda9mWXLkFYTH~w33Xj2O7lcn16BBuZ7sd-SOzzhdjNKpIxJH8gs6Zh9QFyZ0lHt~VfHp3VczmPp7askCq7QiHlQEgfgxBuhafaxx-fwREnjpxZlH5QhfBErPnWdsDZVGv5mCGFRrTMJ3kAfW3EoPBrQYH3nw7Ywykpb3BOnhwXaD7gfbtxSvDgjBK2~N4lRinYqP0nVyamal9pT6WgftSrnpI~ZOpLFPE5tXgsm28CTJxVW-VnKK39ghEslKGRMY4m9RiSIS4TRMm3WL67A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu2.gif\" />\u2060</span>, as this would result in inappropriately small uncertainties on the inferred quantities due to the systematic errors. Simple, commonly adopted models for the likelihood function tend to assume that the measurement error in each pixel is independent and that measurement error is the sole cause of discrepancies between the model and the data. This is not true in the presence of significant systematic effects such as residuals from an incomplete lens galaxy subtraction, and the assumption of a specific form (Gaussian) for the source light profile.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To account for this and obtain realistic uncertainties on <em>b</em> and <em>q</em> despite the use of a simplified model, we adopted the following strategy. This strategy has previously been briefly discussed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b15\" data-open=\"b15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brewer et al. (2011a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">c)</a> and will be presented in depth in a forthcoming contribution (Brewer et al., in preparation).</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We carry out the sampling of the posterior distribution for the lens model parameters using a nested sampling algorithm (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b46\" data-open=\"b46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Skilling 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b16\" data-open=\"b16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brewer, P\u00e1rtay &amp; Cs\u00e1nyi 2011b</a>). Rather than simply sampling the posterior distribution (which would yield unrealistic small uncertainties due to the presence of systematics and the simplified model), we explore the dependence of the posterior distribution for the parameters \u03b8 on the temperature <em>T</em>:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m5\" content-id=\"m5\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><a class=\"jumplink-placeholder\"  id=\"mnras0422-3574-m5.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-m5.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=X4SLcFtS8hGq7a7UPUvZC8hcmb1-1u5Qf7dsCaFoLkI4GPy-bnphHzXx5Cs15~Xg-gfK0KxMXWGyE26ytOLQg3SJnZPFe4gZzhhYG-a6aizBjoJrQtSAWxLanUMePc4BLjkjanUCm8dFDNUYuvawEPv2YwLXN1BztxZ0UgTMVIVNWOtFQJCzFz8FaD4kkjRhP-zZX-Z8hwQkD62qEKBvffD4WN56uw9XxEISpVOx83OdwFN4dQmM5GkPzrft2QP9tSE5GFdqOFD5SfF1d6VZmamw8QJn4UDFbwBuvhiW1~~H3jAIO5X6a-2e~1DuABhoFlv931~CxTy2-csEpwscFw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-m5.gif\" /></a></div></div><span class=\"label\">5</span></div> where \u03b8 denotes the parameters of the lens model, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu3.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=DbLmFp84syrlqKggClpjfGv0jZw7HtyZplEPjcNMYU2I~X2wNvHbjHaeJ6xXH67rF3CqHJwhqqTtxkQBFvMR69e7gen4Sw0Oj66UVAhWqdIp6V5K5-vcSqIw07XCfgHIykgI8tF8wtTaaVGDghb1HB5Sv9hoqkWcNe4PkEriZWe4kCWYNdVip4J6wqgZ~IaIpZjK28cmskziV561pIVV~Z6bSLNKzGXphShYj2ecsipyqXadc5aSxxtRMnah0~29vlAfgGZ28nSXcPMW8wwpDgH2V2sgqCdWRbP~ijcDzH0vbIGNgpwwOvGFyGewclBgh3eUUxMmcPEYS0TXirXTPg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu3.gif\" /></span> is the prior and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu4.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=Hg9DkJ~~ugCyVrzCx0eai891s5N50Z235TFRpblDKAdvymLCrT4RptxC0HseEJ7yHXBalMC222GjVeBvpvLUij34UVf2pnSl2n1H1rAaRLP8c7ZQN6sEL8ZIjC6b7YAo-wY8ikd9DbHXRoAM29wSCZM5tR8h~TcMcpZ93hzUyGxr4xP04tt2JkkJyRPq5iRN37FXvfUphG6dlIavmocIA6mipKiPSjJBACmvnffbpZqzR5uOKPqUTkoqPg7-1ayVfQJ~7KT-OsCTV2OHMxpg76ZFDZOtQk-ZggeMKdINKLBgHT3mPIOdnuiyth4zerRV0ZkjLlRJYRmBlkm0ifRFfA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu4.gif\" /></span> is the standard likelihood function. The temperature controls how conservative the posterior distribution is: <em>T</em>=\u221e reproduces the prior and <em>T</em>= 1 gives the standard posterior obtained by ignoring the systematics.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each system, we then choose the highest temperature <em>T</em> for which the posterior distribution over predicted lensed images (the third panel in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f4\" data-open=\"f4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 4</a>) matches the gross lensed features seen in the data. In other words, we force the posterior distribution to be as conservative as possible while still fitting the morphological features of the lensed images that are believed to be robust. Note that using a temperature <em>T</em> is analogous to increasing the noise standard deviations on the data by a factor <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu5.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=zf2zbGtvXvFqWGBiZbiXBsg~82b0yFacR~ZsakunI1ghf5um-ZwsiEIjndY0-wmxE5577VQtNJM~jmmUD1aw8YSEfuHip1j7mfA4VMT2ezfmTxtTjYahAH2hZ85JDI33heyWbPAmLSsGCvelT-m7TPQMMzJUcPJ0l8zdD58EuI1wIfZoc3AvtUy1hGRNucWTBOPC5txHGQ5frkrqnpjoyGRG3pW~qGc-bExmu42BllRkNpXHljsrJozZjdEtJhVCKVfaHDm6-tvFzBwuBSECLsRU21SVjS3xGze~a0sI7Xxi31hOm7cVAYUBXQdZThk2c5VsJ38O3MmS3zY7Z6NgRw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu5.gif\" />\u2060</span>. This procedure does not change the values of our best estimates for the lens model parameters, but does increase the uncertainty around these estimates. Not carrying out this procedure would result in substantially underestimated uncertainties.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">See <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f4\" data-open=\"f4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 4</a> for images of the lenses, along with galaxy-subtracted images, lens models (chosen at random from the posterior distribution) and the residuals of the lens model fits. In several cases there are significant residuals remaining after the fitting procedure; these are generally due to the source having more structure than the surface brightness model that was assumed. In all cases the lensing aperture mass estimates are reliable.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92408832 id=\"92408832\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-3>3.3\u2002Notes on individual systems</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section we give brief notes on the image configurations of the lens models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>0820+4847</em>. Very little curvature is present in the arc. No definite counter-image is detected. An elliptical source is required, and the deflector is inferred to be very flat.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>0822+1828</em>. Multiple (three) source components are required. This results in tight constraints on the lens model parameters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>0841+3824</em>. Two source components are required. Whereas a bimodal posterior PDF is found, one mode is chosen because of unrealistic small axis ratios for the other modes. A consistent lens model for this system has also been presented by B08.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>0915+4211</em>. Straightforward fit of the arc and counter-image with a single circular source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>0930+2855</em>. Significant residuals due to the assumptions of no shear and isothermality (Auger et al., in preparation). The source has very high surface brightness and the system is an example of an early-type/early-type lensing system (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>0955+0101</em>. Straightforward fit of arc and counter-image with a double image configuration. A consistent lens model for this system has also been presented by B08.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1021+2028</em>. We fit to the arc only. A bimodal solution was found, but we could rule out the mode which did predict a distant unseen counter-image.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1029+0420</em>. Classic double image configuration. A consistent lens model for this system has also been presented by B08.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1032+5322</em>. Arc and counter-image are well modelled by a single circular source. A consistent lens model for this system has also been presented by B08.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1103+5322</em>. Arc can be explained by a single circular source imaged four times. Lens model parameters are tightly constrained. A consistent lens model for this system has also been presented by B08.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1111+2234</em>. Arc can be explained by a single circular source imaged four times. Lens model parameters are tightly constrained.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1117+4704</em>. The single circular source is lensed into a quad configuration. Lens model parameters are tightly constrained.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1135+3720</em>. The arc structure is complex, requiring two components for a good fit. Position of the counter-image is uncertain. Lens parameter constraints are not particularly tight.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1203+2535</em>. Position and morphology of the arc can be reproduced by a single circular source. Subtraction of the deflector galaxy was not straightforward for this system, leaving residuals that may add systematic uncertainties.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1251-0208</em>. Classic double image configuration. A consistent lens model for this system has also been presented by B08.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1313+0506</em>. Arc is well matched by a lensed circular source, but due to the non-detection of a counter-image, the constraints on the lens model parameters are weak.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1331+3638</em>. Classic cusp configuration leads to strong constraints on the lens model parameters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1422+4134</em>. This is the only grade \u2018B\u2019 lens system for which a plausible model has currently been obtained. The two compact images are possibly double images of a background quasar. This configuration yields weak constraints on the lens model, and the inferred stellar mass fractions place this system as a significant outlier from the relation in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>, possibly due to its significant dust content or a potential misidentification of the source redshift. Hence, this system has been excluded from the IMF analysis of Section 4.</p>                        <a id=\"92408865\" scrollto-destination=\"92408865\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=IFeuTJJebRw52SKyk6rbxvch0xqR5HQXMFR6kdt5heg7QTbiRWVKOUTAiD420ftf19geBhrbRuTL9JhUE9y06Son-FuHEWEvS9Hwd9x9~H7CNdQ7ERpvcDtWNqwlsMX6zwgEVhNlKORm64ssXbXxWRHOYdK71dZ4gn2tUCHAxWCyBdhRNguTRNsbu061RrtoGR7mITdYECzXn7UQnewDjBJDApAUC2aeXAtzvTOf0-nswlD0bzCTMihiuEc5oepj1fwvuzRNVEh7CmGvMX3iGoL9BPxm0AyUlqjXoaZ37nuaCzu8njX0EDas6nP5ZoCnG7RZ8rb11vSUz2mZ8MiYfQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Stellar mass fraction within the critical curve versus lensing velocity dispersion for the SWELLS sample. The SLACS sample (with duplicates in SWELLS removed) (Auger et al. 2009) is also plotted for comparison. Note that, at the low-mass end (to the left of the dashed line at \u03c3SIE &lt; 230\u2003km\u2003s\u22121), the Salpeter IMF assumption results in inferred stellar mass fractions greater than unity, which is unphysical.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408865/mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408865\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=5IrBkqhBqTRl-HYQ67ska3KwvQjQNL9LHNIIeJ7g3edbVGsRSNEGW36NKry3IfHd~37lxHMoAzoPO-fdb9Zm9g7I~rtzRxL8MhTBnlJ~r79xMoaNkMG3Qqo7gBwJs8Mvp5YtVj~LpY3oOwxvt1UATZLalHMRFeyunLCSwdksuycJr68~k0oo83kQLARstCwZ6ghnX56dMJvcm4PeGfK0RTMWE4bPGN2G3KJDn0ErcCTOFU3XFdDzFO~m~pqlEiVDs9v04TQzC15fYQ3nAmMaOPC~VWTbeF14T1DPI8W1qWYPx1iUb8DYDp1MhNnR9EE0xoV0-JvcHCAJI~5CW2hJpg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408865&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Stellar mass fraction within the critical curve versus lensing velocity dispersion for the SWELLS sample. The SLACS sample (with duplicates in SWELLS removed) (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>) is also plotted for comparison. Note that, at the low-mass end (to the left of the dashed line at \u03c3<sub>SIE</sub> &lt; 230\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup>), the Salpeter IMF assumption results in inferred stellar mass fractions greater than unity, which is unphysical.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=IFeuTJJebRw52SKyk6rbxvch0xqR5HQXMFR6kdt5heg7QTbiRWVKOUTAiD420ftf19geBhrbRuTL9JhUE9y06Son-FuHEWEvS9Hwd9x9~H7CNdQ7ERpvcDtWNqwlsMX6zwgEVhNlKORm64ssXbXxWRHOYdK71dZ4gn2tUCHAxWCyBdhRNguTRNsbu061RrtoGR7mITdYECzXn7UQnewDjBJDApAUC2aeXAtzvTOf0-nswlD0bzCTMihiuEc5oepj1fwvuzRNVEh7CmGvMX3iGoL9BPxm0AyUlqjXoaZ37nuaCzu8njX0EDas6nP5ZoCnG7RZ8rb11vSUz2mZ8MiYfQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Stellar mass fraction within the critical curve versus lensing velocity dispersion for the SWELLS sample. The SLACS sample (with duplicates in SWELLS removed) (Auger et al. 2009) is also plotted for comparison. Note that, at the low-mass end (to the left of the dashed line at \u03c3SIE &lt; 230\u2003km\u2003s\u22121), the Salpeter IMF assumption results in inferred stellar mass fractions greater than unity, which is unphysical.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408865/mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408865\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=5IrBkqhBqTRl-HYQ67ska3KwvQjQNL9LHNIIeJ7g3edbVGsRSNEGW36NKry3IfHd~37lxHMoAzoPO-fdb9Zm9g7I~rtzRxL8MhTBnlJ~r79xMoaNkMG3Qqo7gBwJs8Mvp5YtVj~LpY3oOwxvt1UATZLalHMRFeyunLCSwdksuycJr68~k0oo83kQLARstCwZ6ghnX56dMJvcm4PeGfK0RTMWE4bPGN2G3KJDn0ErcCTOFU3XFdDzFO~m~pqlEiVDs9v04TQzC15fYQ3nAmMaOPC~VWTbeF14T1DPI8W1qWYPx1iUb8DYDp1MhNnR9EE0xoV0-JvcHCAJI~5CW2hJpg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408865&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Stellar mass fraction within the critical curve versus lensing velocity dispersion for the SWELLS sample. The SLACS sample (with duplicates in SWELLS removed) (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>) is also plotted for comparison. Note that, at the low-mass end (to the left of the dashed line at \u03c3<sub>SIE</sub> &lt; 230\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup>), the Salpeter IMF assumption results in inferred stellar mass fractions greater than unity, which is unphysical.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>1703+2451</em>. Arc and counter-image can be explained by a single circular source.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>2141-0001</em>. As discussed in Paper II, the arc appears to be split into three images, but this is likely due to the presence of two dust lanes. The arc morphology can be explained by a single circular source. The posterior distribution includes models where the arc is split into distinct images, as well as models where the arc is continuous.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408873 id=\"92408873\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4>4\u2002COMPARING STELLAR MASS AND LENSING MASS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section we derive lensing and stellar masses within the critical curves (Section 4.1), and compare them to derive limits on the stellar in IMF (Section 4.2).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92408875 id=\"92408875\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1>4.1\u2002Lensing and stellar masses within the critical curves</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As in Paper I, we fit the surface brightness models to the available high-resolution imaging, i.e. the <em>HST</em> and Keck-AO imaging, using the multicolour fitting code <span class=\"small-caps\">spasmoid</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bennert et al. 2011</a>). The stellar mass (and surface brightness) model consists of an <em>n</em>= 4 S\u00e9rsic profile (i.e. a de Vaucouleurs profile) for the bulge and an <em>n</em>= 1 exponential disc component. One advantage of <span class=\"small-caps\">spasmoid</span> over similar methods such as <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Peng et al. 2002</a>) is the ability to take into account prior information such as the fact that the disc component should have a larger effective radius and a higher ellipticity than the bulge. Once we have obtained the surface photometry parameters, we infer the stellar masses of the bulge and disc components using a Bayesian method for fitting SPS models to multiband photometric data (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>). This method uses a grid of models output from a standard SPS code, and allows for marginalization over unknown parameters such as star formation history, metallicity, etc. A summary of the structural properties (stellar masses, sizes and axis ratios) of the SWELLS cycle 18 targets with multiband imaging is given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t3\" data-open=\"t3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Tables 3</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t4\" data-open=\"t4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. For the other lenses we use the structural parameters as reported in Paper I.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We then integrate these models to obtain the total stellar mass <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu6.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=MeajLLC-dxUeWrYU7mBJX0buG9CB8LPhs0BcAk~dB9Cb-wrcMv0fVtl0koLmImDXmJs0LnQpqY3uNr9RkTpYfrB0h7qikGPsGIP033x-r6fjrTvwGVSsRiABDT-Jkn-el4GopBADBMFsodla~p7-wHNAVfSy1-J4eybDIz2G6r0LdDzjyPTwbpJUBdaY-58qCGvJHuruAKYmjcSoTL3ydAgMhOvGNx~C57hXZNZbX5zAIpPJne0BCRFnv1OxJYCIKBu8727d0GD-cUtNeqtjkuuQnwRl2JSGtyFU9Z8oVzheogaOXA-o924YoOGT8PqmDJx0q-URIXQQv1MH-3TNGw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu6.gif\" /></span> within the critical curve. This can be compared with the inferred mass within the critical curve from lensing (<em>M</em><sub>lens</sub>), yielding stellar mass fractions <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu7.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=T2BlwUsHy39oB2CHng-metzR5wDRKRTyFEwTp2oL8pu9h0ueBC-k-I~gjd83LSit-hCaP9BxyRiU8bEuMLRxK~i-8OBcd-YmL055dgj-55nebbGKVPY9kljrSorIxQqH~LbhVM3CUBmbKj-29s3667XkVp398q8mfTESYK94VxorujnCkx~6~0lHzV~bs4ymzLpPoAtzxg6eatf5zkC1-W-1XrGLodjKcwuYk39bNJT5GyYEEdxHLPV8IEAq5YoNy5fj-bSQ9~gFy4osqW7y5~eiZZSf8onHZN3XxxTC6Ox3ccu1PMdprOVcWLUJFgkSrCyCUYnXXSwulALdCqySKw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu7.gif\" /></span> under both the Chabrier IMF assumption and the Salpeter IMF assumption. The reason for the choice of the critical curve as the integration aperture is that, heuristically, it is the aperture within which the mass of the lens is most strongly constrained (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b54\" data-open=\"b54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu 2010</a>, and references therein). To obtain uncertainties on the stellar mass fractions, we Monte Carlo sample from the posterior distribution for the lens model parameters and the posterior distributions for the total stellar mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The resulting stellar mass fractions for the grade \u2018A\u2019 lenses, under the Chabrier and Salpeter assumptions, are plotted in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a> as a function of lensing velocity dispersion (a proxy for overall galaxy mass that can be measured accurately and independent of the size of the Einstein radius and the normalization of the stellar IMF). Remarkably, there is a smooth declining trend as a function of stellar velocity dispersion over more than a factor of 2 in stellar velocity dispersion (and a factor of \u223c10 in stellar mass). This trend can be due to two effects: (i) a systematic variation of the IMF; and (ii) a varying dark matter fraction within the Einstein radius due to a change in stellar mass-to-dark matter ratio and the change in physical size of the Einstein radius. Disentangling the two effects is a major goal of the SWELLS survey and requires very realistic lensing and dynamical models (e.g. Paper II). However, as we will show in the rest of this paper, a very robust inference on the normalization of the IMF at the low velocity dispersion end can be obtained based on a very simple argument.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">At the low velocity dispersion end, the Salpeter IMF assumption results in inferred stellar mass fractions greater than unity, which is clearly unphysical, especially considering that there may be an additional contribution of cold gas distributed as the stars (Paper II and references therein). This provides evidence against the Salpeter IMF and any IMF that would predict a similar or greater stellar mass. In Section 4.2 we formalize this argument with a probabilistic model and derive quantitative constraints on the IMF for the lower mass (\u03c3<sub>SIE</sub> &lt; 230\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup>) SWELLS galaxies.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92408880 id=\"92408880\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-2>4.2\u2002Constraints on the initial mass function</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Our data do not allow us to probe the form of the IMF, but they do allow us to place robust constraints on the integral of the IMF: if the assumed IMF yields a mass significantly greater than the inferred total mass from lensing (i.e. a stellar mass fraction much greater than unity), then this IMF is excluded by our data. We could assume that all of our galaxies have the same underlying central stellar mass fraction <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu8.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=VLb3-~DCe4D0IVfJHMU0s6-TQbYkRAxSn8Gz~mHL1qBYUaWhm1aLhgafwRlWG524VUlyDuHYx4F-t4wNL-dAi~G9T2VHED1pbmwWGMCXswEmqiZApXWefuogqRjZSH5V9~HeFUaJy7aGT2YLXiZjoGucm0uv1juU4UesOj1WysdbyeAPnGJKaXo9V1tw3zsWEGJm1R~hO4oeuaZILFfKOVCXqZk0XNuB-wNz6VTtKkKlcbWKJlTm4nYK01X~OOxE0-t7~3ku9LkG0hy-Vi3xDhsT~LpxOMwynP1imo-oo0GXZU5jjlW0jC5Y7AvULO4VpqZ~u5MjVEcDwD4oWnTilg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu8.gif\" />\u2060</span>, in which case the estimate for a Salpeter IMF (i.e. the variance-weighted mean of the points in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>) would imply <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu9.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=lnwhYVBdFHXgwfVNYuOcrq9j9fQMe2EAkay0FYsT17tJ2oVuaE3ilbnLGUBm1d3PNXf6gPXOkoaVWepk0-EcXNwYk8cCGge44PaEIVf03ZcZIQN8Z8LzDpaWS5zn3q-C9WJlKF3opqCu84-gmHoTdtMOufolxbHG1dlmWz6eGEEnu-mBm7SsNv5TuGhm5EDL4LPTqp2OlJ5mixT~MYA8S1uDSLy56DXavplXA7Fukmaoa-I3yENG32HIOFYISKhb9MtYpyVfUufBpb8i8VKvt0w-gyM5Gl~B9uIlCpTiXtOsy3HJ5nWPEOx3c9gTQfkqfFpVrG7-BjCHyh-DxLuZEQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu9.gif\" />\u2060</span>. However, there is certainly some amount of scatter in the central dark matter fraction and therefore in the stellar mass fraction. We therefore explicitly build a model for the true underlying stellar mass fraction that includes Gaussian scatter and the fact that <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu10.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=UEglIjc9UZz92hOJjFfkat87LMSYpAmI2kphTRjeJXf5SibHOw9M-tNZka4uFNeyyt6NfVySiuVlYBDozmifuRwB4LZG9lf1fGEMQjLjHUXv8Lxtvgx9ZO4oD~veg2N1OXBBhgikxUC4bAggcTlvQ57myDzlnS7OvXJ1rflUt~LMrHThaU91Ad~QnFyxxJJ3vHZlnUZziNd3wUjOd6Odc~ex-7Fx-oavZX6lH1pHjSWJSriPkq-WqoD4vAJW6A9vCjLSAWgiNou~jCSzfsDA8E0H4EIJqbSLG8iM4gWuBAky0gTo6EANqHlT8MF~gMX80BFPgKYKbI2W0~LJyMvwdA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu10.gif\" /></span> is between 0 and 1. In practice, this is a truncated normal distribution, which we parametrize as having a peak at \u03bc and characteristic width \u03c3. Then the probability of observing a set of galaxies with true stellar mass fractions {<em>F</em>*} is given by<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m6\" content-id=\"m6\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><a class=\"jumplink-placeholder\"  id=\"mnras0422-3574-m6.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-m6.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=GQSSh3rkKEs4ey8cCrgw9p1HIT2-NH7m~M7WmDAGQ-Jb9I8c8OSh0ElDlrjtWkHM3zx-4Lv5kARUB2Xq8z0BRJ8PSLaIOifgA1Tl-WtbP2E8xv4sq2cE3ReqTT~x~~8O6vcnJj-uOS~q2XEvSPIF3CQfu-RZAwiG4d0lQHyaUcJYTK0wO~701-wRlU2eVzM9Zabt7-w9uwmiQeeBmcsJPTxojoOIKhumnUHFuQcbPfwJ4MrwhGmleTWBFZKWyhM7P2RAmAgm95ghYHf1G4RCwUqYafRIc45L95pWmuI32DxmTE-wq~BydgWQ3gvxdb7qn2H0laPSV7zOb4i2HW6eXg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-m6.gif\" /></a></div></div><span class=\"label\">6</span></div> where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu11.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=SGDa4hsCzBLmT0YzvmuLjtAuKF5-fQi6TbOn5Ol7NZcuxFmgoNs5HMXP4~0NqPC6kN-hfq3MMZMMA~30qpNbPfMsjeAjQH14hV6kph~B4VGMberR2TXCsF8ybMr1DRu7-ix6XLVSYxApiCpehgKO1WETS9FPaq8EqIN4ijm3m0N8O~jR1n~rJfZLsxN0KkJuCCMvA~2dVT4wDSfnfY2JrQ5Fr2fcK6DPJQdgfiCKAWH1CRrxsRWob39jG0kgUTjDfH-8sNt9yRz8p~ml1s84hBtRtEdWGHAULUCAsE6mxXdf~6iEE3A2mTTuiU3awZ4SHQb2Megz0pl3z2QEN1957Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu11.gif\" />\u2060</span>. We also introduce a parameter \u03b1 that parametrizes the difference between a true (unknown) normalization of the IMF and the normalization resulting from a Salpeter IMF:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m7\" content-id=\"m7\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><a class=\"jumplink-placeholder\"  id=\"mnras0422-3574-m7.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-m7.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=AAcFjIzsKywlbyZFxOrJOArRVjB5~SVNmkSBHmBMsDHQD76dDSaErsdEr7BUgxPgBGhzzl0RYIGwD2fbly8fFOmDwVeonYE5HR1Zv03cjGlKCm0J4gqD0dTQrXtj69FdsjFE9qRY~~Kp0vjHHn1XiDsLLrCNT0mH5t85pHlruq6jgJ97hXAgivNOW07pFmRcYKzjG4JNNtDfQKJJBFX5SAG~gdg3OcCZEtt3c-Taehw4FfabfUmbo7yoTYG3hdWSn1oN~yqWGDyxjpyWQtepZLsiJEIKOd4BAIV2S-MyMBC10XdEOcackZM0c1rSOUmkioux-A2REPdWv802Z0QpDQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-m7.gif\" /></a></div></div></div> This normalization is always greater than 0, and \u03b1= 1 implies a Salpeter IMF (a Chabrier IMF typically would imply \u03b1\u223c 0.55). At fixed total mass, an increase in \u03b1 yields an increase in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu12.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=y~AeursJTcufLgwvG-Xz2Z79Titw~1-wunzsCdh-VRyXYFpovk9fma1vgaR6Gvz~-NA1nOoLki5abms1-TXKF9CLJDXYMOzMec0pz0VoX8nsfHTukLGcMyJaH1fOnM1mdVE4uRfGOmuwBn6SZB1UsiRytVxaCR7o7mpBD8t0ZQorOSydD-QW~5UunQnpQAUIeqnfjsVV5bUiFbIaNjT94ueHWjBOCJatUjPM65x5nobXGAXBUGwiqtAVkPbaGTZ1b6iH9swNckGnBVGb7W7K3R7solrPirbS1RsvAjvb3JtEtawx-qLKprESNThZjPSnD-Q2INkK8GV2WcFadlkqLQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu12.gif\" />\u2060</span>, demonstrating that the parameters are highly degenerate. However, as noted previously, \u03b1 cannot be raised to arbitrarily large values because the stellar mass fraction is bounded to be less than unity. In practice, \u03b1 plays a similar role to a stellar mass-to-light ratio but has the benefit of being less dependent on dust and age due to having explicitly modelled the spectral energy distributions of the galaxies (see Section 4.1).</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Given our data \u2013 total masses from lensing and stellar masses assuming a Salpeter-like normalization of the IMF \u2013 and invoking Bayes\u2019 theorem allow us to write down the probability distribution for our unknown model parameters \u03bc, \u03c3, \u03b1 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu13.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=zvwWNwYiYIUFAyDVKyMJLqhR-HtAbTmzrf-uYXqcyLOY24B7sWgjn5qK3TMy-n0171DTl2K908c0Pn8ks2t1cRhr6TtEFKLE7WgmzFHbEnO~bqWKZxHXlrQKrwOql4r0TINdthUg7lt2ULyuzvOZr2hywnu~IrqADDDO6xGgAVTKg8MsoGPD~41JGLGizsImn9puqJqnIKQu7bL-D8ovw1Y8XsrCAHrvBkalNmqJW4lEi12IwVrTtU3sAod3cYrZlUcm3ZQD87KhS5r2kUsYBwbPMJzrxx0wlsoNS9AIr7~1GGcVu~exWWY2B0AtKwqyWQbGkNuBKsDwD~CHbkjGuw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu13.gif\" />\u2060</span>, given the data:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m8\" content-id=\"m8\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><a class=\"jumplink-placeholder\"  id=\"mnras0422-3574-m8.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" content-id=\"m9\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><a class=\"jumplink-placeholder\"  id=\"mnras0422-3574-m9.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-m9.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=Nxm5vRWmymuu7wVyfFbWD9fIxp42bWZjlwUx~~VFesQtwmNZXRtd1PoGvnCjEdU-8GAfAPkArYd2wRhKoah9kmxPO9c~pe~Ob-r0hsFCPFYWEQdhMN05dJndDGmfCWEOsGJmhpKhWg9aDy~maPvXrFDSoOpMQfCyvVNv~HedbFo-L-L7ovjSkTa-jDYSN86hxC-4TUiC9pW4Ud-zeVDPVS8QiMbpfAy0-a5rD283IsQX-4chUKEqJ~3zioY8sSrVywDXTcY1zmks1Z4KudcigIt57rLskcgSZgCz2kaGlW4UaOzUfMqtXKVYHQLLdaaIS0KuBPx4CkwI0-yaQrtfEg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-m9.gif\" /></a></div></div><span class=\"label\">8</span></div> where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu14.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=i4~x89heBOUOIwSugcl~5fVQ3G7wqn0duaw6z8D-UzvhmflEyvr7PNgBxiQpjISf~TA7tSFPkmXvvH1vOeFNo3M8n0cvYLObZ8raE~QZa-9hhr4atLM7vuWZRlqD1kZWVyMSoZKzeooRKgnJlCUgNOi4sQQcWwQANyIjUjsMlaphcV4W8TzAdAGm5SxF4VbIG2xs~vlXgiNkY7M888GtfXklenooQt5TUGsklsXEpo1~NWoQns6MR~tvt2C2K4VaKqvhfNLzTpygijt00ahIaIFLVJxnC9x1yw9U1EOfz5wD4d37sw1KOulxlTu-nLtLqCGBl~42JNyzMFj-O5BfEA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu14.gif\" /></span> are the scaled observed stellar mass fraction, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu15.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=Cgtop3Dm5a7vauUq3MASARSdNdL8GBP0Tc34NaRul5-eKqmotqqKa1vyihq6e73AyPbIZCPt8esZwpV~V6ZNAq7SX6TTJURHaXuugF9c25-LvFiUv7LPN5vDvpKvl8NuI3ELkGoL0iHOvV6EMixCrXeqVifJPdoRBsCogzsoQ8vMZ2M47QuNTf3eVUDO1vB9YY47c7nLjdOIbCTIZpcFFT2E~yhg~kbT6xMbRnenOoS64WmhHf3aS72R6WJ9LQC56a1Gie0-pPutss-QhiVWRvgVPIV6vFwvKKDTdSfjjQEfD0jBV8g35r43fPln3PUPTHt4XcTlr1FDpmhr7G1KHg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu15.gif\" /></span> is the set of true (unknown) stellar mass fractions and the leading terms are priors on \u03b1, \u03bc and \u03c3. The term <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu16.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=ytekUqXLxKt95EEiEU6B5JPk0PdHN6EquiGIvJaq29Evh6da53fCvRsZOfmPku1kKfrRa1TcYwOQh~cvb0E8E0yenYlteuEE0in7L7Ku0cb34Ma1QRtdpxqpFPNRW9Gk4h3q4noVV2oPUnuoOZEcsaXBVdVxvc4F60~yYX4hzXURASEwkK2-RsuaHi3za7zpYqDrWpRnNGham63oRW8SnAf4mFMxmjOtaKGr~uS8cY-qOZEH5G6AyOB3BImXF7TBXJrvB9nGnZxyY6t4eR4TOy5La6cJvOOtpGnW5ehnrgckJ9Z6kjFibo06HdWxVZx3rVGQNWO1Fsm1XjbcRZi1fQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu16.gif\" /></span> is given by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m6\"></span><a href=\"#m6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">equation (6)</a> and the term <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu17.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=d56JFFhaQCgw6NX8jhwojhqkU9oNNDm3wBFtZhJoeOz8Bg-d6atFa7vSaBUygrA4qk0IcVMUes4xCcpLS~3vyXuDhMKTByNet3BH~oI2ZHgQuGAuGYaTgTLIcQroURNtPZIE8elIt4MUFaLjUmdRvH3qiSMcEMrPRun3K1-vB7czab3THmedVCGRIBWaGYpQDyT951zeWh22JSERWXrmt293hA2yls29hVpRrWq8mP4l9Z0SO4d47jogFr~7nv9C7hpnBY~Q9Eorwe1phePByZPGFyehUiy0Ikh~BJYo3DsDag8sY8BO37pRE4~1kU-GNniFHCwzQLE9MVVb1J-Ctg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu17.gif\" /></span> is the likelihood of having observed the data, taken to be a multivariate normal distribution with means <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-mu18.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=yRxwMKqR~J6ZkhXfDWzse6ZH5B5eY3-2NfGiKIWAuHRUakLGpdxMnHOMNMhCZETZMiQKYCUPG1AtEM1q-exBcQAQO7iupb6~IBXYAPQg27pevG2WIn5l5e3tHsRkTAdmsWGUWcclWu0C5Jd2-W-OUbA0NdLcU4iLq4gaAkKSYuhjK3dm4xMyXJoL2mRVGfQ7kTm-SiU7T49KYOuaykPzrEi20CEzYlm3CGSuPkMeRbK9IgWTbccdyNdhtum0S4UIS0oLo0uDUtf-3YEahyEyJrjS9UZGb5n6uN1uqmYLxi-G43oNLKCbb7wBi6CesebJyav28AJokvnL7WvwvuBvxA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-mu18.gif\" /></span> and standard deviations given by the measurement uncertainties (the galaxies are independent and there are therefore no covariances).</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The inferences on the parameters (\u03bc, \u03c3, \u03b1) were computed using Markov chain Monte Carlo, with the true <em>F</em>* explicitly integrated out:<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m10\" content-id=\"m10\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><a class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" href=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-m10.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=L7WNaD7NPWn32SAadcbWwl6ilGrhzFj2F-c-cCcRcKwnIZYWyO-Q5P16mjn5rEH0yoM17HGZBcc~4zALBaNf2a3mb3fPF3SyksiqFDnrLZyuciYUTGZDS-SCzMw4dRSCJc4BJH~jTdM7WhIoI6Tpza77OOeaW8Ode8yUENmv807C-9KQ3ajTUnOqn6cajA0dHEnpHxabEgeTxsxeo7kjbKC1VhpuPpjWBdzdaB7XVrb4IvkBnGQWGLCzya8AhwU0b0Ueb2OBp~HmrupdBM7uUnD4Yd-~D0zvnUWWBD4D4wd~0N0J06xdA4sK0GEs8yXWgo~RDYGCCknyMEU-bczgbA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" id=\"mnras0422-3574-m10.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-m10.gif?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=20tYk5GuBi~F3GXzhmT~KNvadnYgoSoDXeYN-6LNlmLre1c1rz6a7-7m9bFUugX0tfSpQ1MCtjdbVLXCjfkLzya~-haOAYl2z0l-7JjuTqxcZLWfjClUqiRd3tyCHFrp8acNGBGdnkikg8Mi1K1VKx3rVyc8rmrHmG~qr8Jicz4787WHSglCQ7IrdXJ5zfrL0Mlga051k9gxVCm3drFXWJzDPC4JwwvneKhsSMx74OXYJq-pvkv1uDv5O3R3~WAjYy~Axf99X19YBxh1poQGK-L2MBampBE4GJP2p4oDwRscW3Pa1FxWx8Vey1zUgO6Vose1bEBfmoznFdcYAvDttg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-m10.gif\" /></a></div></div><span class=\"label\">9</span></div> \u2003These inferences were calculated assuming a uniform prior on \u03bc (a location parameter) between 0 and 1, a log-uniform prior on \u03c3 (a scale parameter) between 0.01 and 1, and a log-uniform prior on \u03b1 (a scale parameter) between 0.2 and 5, all independent. The results are shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f6\" data-open=\"f6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 6</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. Values of \u03b1 less than about 0.9 are approximately equally plausible, but the evidence strongly disfavours values of \u03b1 greater than unity. The evidence for the point hypothesis \u03b1= 0.5 is only about twice that of the point hypothesis \u03b1= 1; however, the probability that the IMF is lighter than Salpeter is 98 per\u2003cent. This result depends slightly on the chosen prior for \u03bc, \u03b1 and \u03c3, and becomes weaker if a greater prior probability is implicitly assigned to the hypothesis that the intrinsic <em>F</em>* values are clustered close to 1. For example, if the prior bounds on \u03bc are extended to \u22120.1 and 1.1, allowing the true <em>F</em>* distribution to place most of its mass near 1, the posterior probability that the IMF is lighter than Salpeter is slightly reduced to 93 per\u2003cent. The intrinsic scatter on the true <em>F</em>* values is inferred to be small (\u03c3 &lt; 0.16 with 95 per\u2003cent probability).</div>                        <a id=\"92408884\" scrollto-destination=\"92408884\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f6.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=Zohvi94GG-ypykuzMyY-6TMXbT04~cob6ft4oJIgbCTG563H6Cy82kpigvNaLcbUs0RWWqA4knnQUrruHZ4Urzgpj4mgbJhnT2ie59cZra8vxhqk9NbbmY-OxSdiFAlD~oj6pTm27uWoNq4V8QAhvrv61Qe7vDWfgSqFRX0METxxpHUcDutLLxMVMzAJmGSIUoDnWpGxz6Z-bou7ei~mc5LtMFhLHsRWSmcqg1RU2QwsBZSNC9iuqxW-Yk0GRoDRKCovA9E0mwdMOfRbDSKx9OXTda5V9~Xt97ZN9j1Zmrh6rs0LBJ5JUFq3BzK1zG62aezYQnq7e~jvqWWlA8P0Yw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Inference on the IMF mismatch parameter \u03b1 and the parameter \u03bc, the mean of the true distribution of stellar mass fractions. Values of \u03b1 less than about 0.9 are approximately equally plausible, but the evidence strongly disfavours higher values of \u03b1. The vertical line denotes the Salpeter IMF, and the dashed line indicates a Chabrier-like (in terms of mass-to-light ratio) IMF. The probability that the IMF is lighter than Salpeter is 98 per\u2003cent.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408884/mnras0422-3574-f6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408884\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f6.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=FvoTm91UOgl-Z7l8dz3hr9doqkl4JGZZXijZI3kddwJ9OB5I3wUfSRSsBCOSESnO9eQS8zbjix9NKmu2w~5w8b3KQe-UMkAuiwRibkuunV4oOnkRI6YQRdPCy7EoSZONKKgKkaJaeO23NXLBQumGacCtoldSB6j3vgypHBXA9z8piLr5CAs7pP44eC0gzb5n-Lb0Ib71CdB0L4AepoYaKS7QLhKRTsUA0zw5ycSxOuNEzAb4gOJd9ZuXoT1j2igDf4JxCbQ81XUvv64u5ukDl6yHZ8AgrmTl8vD4Q26CfKvDIA0~OiJaVXFIZyjdnxmnFZ~AT2j2ri~mVZ7hV4J0ig__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408884&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inference on the IMF mismatch parameter \u03b1 and the parameter \u03bc, the mean of the true distribution of stellar mass fractions. Values of \u03b1 less than about 0.9 are approximately equally plausible, but the evidence strongly disfavours higher values of \u03b1. The vertical line denotes the Salpeter IMF, and the dashed line indicates a Chabrier-like (in terms of mass-to-light ratio) IMF. The probability that the IMF is lighter than Salpeter is 98 per\u2003cent.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f6.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=Zohvi94GG-ypykuzMyY-6TMXbT04~cob6ft4oJIgbCTG563H6Cy82kpigvNaLcbUs0RWWqA4knnQUrruHZ4Urzgpj4mgbJhnT2ie59cZra8vxhqk9NbbmY-OxSdiFAlD~oj6pTm27uWoNq4V8QAhvrv61Qe7vDWfgSqFRX0METxxpHUcDutLLxMVMzAJmGSIUoDnWpGxz6Z-bou7ei~mc5LtMFhLHsRWSmcqg1RU2QwsBZSNC9iuqxW-Yk0GRoDRKCovA9E0mwdMOfRbDSKx9OXTda5V9~Xt97ZN9j1Zmrh6rs0LBJ5JUFq3BzK1zG62aezYQnq7e~jvqWWlA8P0Yw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Inference on the IMF mismatch parameter \u03b1 and the parameter \u03bc, the mean of the true distribution of stellar mass fractions. The vertical line denotes the Salpeter IMF, and the dashed line indicates a Chabrier-like (in terms of mass-to-light ratio) IMF. The probability that the IMF is lighter than Salpeter is 98 per\u2003cent.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"92408885\" scrollto-destination=\"92408885\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=aGJ0RPpcml34~sDRyoJKGv5ayhHreMy5iQZ5RzqnaTcMUjux2dwSNJJW-1GCajJnddChshggefI8kD~2FpliUISxZS0txcWkOIXb-M1pdDPwCTwJmIJaqVxLrOdGw6GYIosP~U~-LjPhEFXMIZLGlax~aCLjbg-sebKzMfuPXsrpRoGy5AlxJ3dOdGPb3LxZMf6795tncbZ4TorNXiYlsIp7xOdEn27cfrzCNQ6IRFKSTcYNZLJEClh7GGRIcyKjd-t0ymodG~RG49MrDX~Y18MOqIkK-Vodw~g1-sId445KI9mAyhDZmTP3fnE8yjs09Am8SMQOqtYuSTo82zLmjA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Inference on the parameter \u03c3, the intrinsic scatter in the true distribution of stellar mass fractions F*. The value of \u03c3 is constrained to be low (&lt;0.16 with 95 per\u2003cent probability), so there is evidence that the intrinsic stellar mass fractions are fairly homogeneous across the low-mass end of the SWELLS sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408885/mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408885\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=fKOza33dNP0OM-0yAELxrevcfZUNgFR~sY4DIBXTBkhzhNrjV4b2kaSc2ehBMS8Rpv0PZGtZh1VgE0zWA4Mdoj9FSx5WBzPknkrGOZNBAyhS-S8hRvoJjkqTJB9bd~IiRpnj2aXzQbo803y493nir43BnMg2yL5NPNU6yZ2pxdzgP1whnr0FAgqwx4Gjqaa6iEh69IwDgTOOk01gNR4xA4XvfQbj2EqHCk-4Uy6Fc3R-tMXMYbNZ0WrKfhejorugTlHTCGpHz9h6jg6Gr-hdQwyelPJIvkJ1U1TKbsZ~qXAYsavV7V8olHIrZr4OpOh0UkOzHFdM-3zV7LRaqxJM1g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408885&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inference on the parameter \u03c3, the intrinsic scatter in the true distribution of stellar mass fractions <em>F</em>*. The value of \u03c3 is constrained to be low (&lt;0.16 with 95 per\u2003cent probability), so there is evidence that the intrinsic stellar mass fractions are fairly homogeneous across the low-mass end of the SWELLS sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=aGJ0RPpcml34~sDRyoJKGv5ayhHreMy5iQZ5RzqnaTcMUjux2dwSNJJW-1GCajJnddChshggefI8kD~2FpliUISxZS0txcWkOIXb-M1pdDPwCTwJmIJaqVxLrOdGw6GYIosP~U~-LjPhEFXMIZLGlax~aCLjbg-sebKzMfuPXsrpRoGy5AlxJ3dOdGPb3LxZMf6795tncbZ4TorNXiYlsIp7xOdEn27cfrzCNQ6IRFKSTcYNZLJEClh7GGRIcyKjd-t0ymodG~RG49MrDX~Y18MOqIkK-Vodw~g1-sId445KI9mAyhDZmTP3fnE8yjs09Am8SMQOqtYuSTo82zLmjA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Inference on the parameter \u03c3, the intrinsic scatter in the true distribution of stellar mass fractions F*. The value of \u03c3 is constrained to be low (&lt;0.16 with 95 per\u2003cent probability), so there is evidence that the intrinsic stellar mass fractions are fairly homogeneous across the low-mass end of the SWELLS sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408885/mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408885\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=fKOza33dNP0OM-0yAELxrevcfZUNgFR~sY4DIBXTBkhzhNrjV4b2kaSc2ehBMS8Rpv0PZGtZh1VgE0zWA4Mdoj9FSx5WBzPknkrGOZNBAyhS-S8hRvoJjkqTJB9bd~IiRpnj2aXzQbo803y493nir43BnMg2yL5NPNU6yZ2pxdzgP1whnr0FAgqwx4Gjqaa6iEh69IwDgTOOk01gNR4xA4XvfQbj2EqHCk-4Uy6Fc3R-tMXMYbNZ0WrKfhejorugTlHTCGpHz9h6jg6Gr-hdQwyelPJIvkJ1U1TKbsZ~qXAYsavV7V8olHIrZr4OpOh0UkOzHFdM-3zV7LRaqxJM1g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408885&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inference on the parameter \u03c3, the intrinsic scatter in the true distribution of stellar mass fractions <em>F</em>*. The value of \u03c3 is constrained to be low (&lt;0.16 with 95 per\u2003cent probability), so there is evidence that the intrinsic stellar mass fractions are fairly homogeneous across the low-mass end of the SWELLS sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Note that, if we take into account the fact that there can be an additional 20 per\u2003cent of mass in cold gas distributed in the same way as the stars (as in Papers II), the probability that the IMF is lighter than Salpeter becomes greater than 99 per\u2003cent. Correspondingly, the 95 per\u2003cent probability upper limit to \u03b1 becomes 0.80.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408887 id=\"92408887\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5>5\u2002DISCUSSION AND COMPARISON WITH PREVIOUS WORK</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The main result of this paper is that the stellar mass of spiral galaxies with lens velocity dispersion between 160 and 230\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup> (i.e. with masses comparable to or slightly above the Milky Way) is lighter than that predicted based on their colours using a Salpeter IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This conclusion is based on a robust and straightforward argument, i.e. the stellar mass cannot exceed the total mass measured by strong gravitational lensing. A high abundance of cold gas would make our result even stronger, requiring even less mass in stars and therefore a lighter normalization of the IMF. Systematic uncertainties in the stellar mass estimates due to differences in SPS models and assumptions are of the order of 0.05\u20130.1\u2003dex for a fixed IMF (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Conroy et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu et al. 2010</a>) and therefore not sufficient to modify our conclusions significantly.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Even though our sample is the largest sample of spiral lens galaxies currently available, it is important to consider whether this result could somehow be biased by unknown selection effects. In Paper I we investigated the selection function in detail by comparing the size mass relation of SWELLS lenses to that of non-lens galaxies selected from SDSS and found them to be statistically equivalent. The detailed analysis of the lens SDSS J2141\u22120001 presented in Paper II indicates that that galaxy might be drawn from the densest part of the distribution of mass density profiles of spiral galaxies. Whether this is a generic feature of lensing selection needs to be verified by the detailed analysis of the entire sample. However, if lens galaxies were representative of the densest spiral galaxies, this would only make our inference stronger with respect to the overall population, since the densest galaxies are likely those with the highest stellar content.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our results are consistent with independent estimates of the normalization of the stellar IMF of spiral galaxies based on a variety of techniques. For example, based on spiral galaxy rotation curves, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bell &amp; de Jong (2001)</a> find that a Salpeter IMF is too heavy and argue for a normalization that is significantly lower. Based on the vertical velocity dispersion of discs, the Disc Mass Survey (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bershady et al. 2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) argues that the mass-to-light ratio (and hence the normalization of the stellar IMF) is significantly lower than that inferred assuming a Salpeter IMF. Interestingly, a qualitatively similar result is found for elliptical galaxies in the same velocity dispersion range. Dynamical arguments (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Cappellari et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. 2012</a>) as well as joint dynamical and lensing arguments (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Barnab\u00e8 et al. 2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) show that a Salpeter IMF is too heavy for low-mass ellipticals.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The light normalization of the stellar IMF (or equivalently mass-to-light ratio) required for spirals and ellipticals comparable to the mass of the Milky Way is in contrast to the heavier normalization required for more massive systems. For example, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b61\" data-open=\"b61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">van Dokkum &amp; Conroy (2010)</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b48\" data-open=\"b48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Spiniello et al. (2011)</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2010b)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b47\" data-open=\"b47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sonnenfeld et al. (2011)</a>, using different techniques and data sets, find that light Chabrier-like IMFs are ruled out for the most massive early-type galaxies, and a heavier IMF is preferred. Further evidence for this hypothesis is provided by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu et al. (2010)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Thomas et al. (2011)</a>\u2013 and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Newman et al. (2011)</a> for the case of massive brightest cluster galaxies \u2013 although those studies could not break completely the degeneracy between dark matter content and normalization of the IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Taken together, these results are consistent with the hypothesis that the stellar IMF is not universal, but that it changes systematically with galaxy stellar velocity dispersion and mass (and therefore halo mass to first approximation). Since stellar velocity dispersion correlates with the age of the stellar populations, this non-universality might reflect the non-universality of the conditions that were prevalent when the stars were formed. The obvious suspects are the density of the gas and the condition of ambient background radiation. A key open question is whether this variation in the IMF can be understood theoretically based on first principles.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is important to emphasize that lensing and dynamical measurements constrain the total normalization of the IMF and not its specific form. Therefore, by themselves they cannot constrain the shape of the IMF and reveal whether the change in the normalization is due to a change in the abundance of low-mass stars or remnants of high-mass stars or any combination thereof. Independent constraints such as those from stellar population diagnostics or from galaxies at different redshifts probing different ranges in stellar mass are necessary to break this degeneracy in the interpretation of the trend.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A final issue that we have not addressed in this paper is how much of the trend shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a> is due to a varying IMF and how much is due to varying dark matter content. For the higher velocity dispersion SLACS galaxies weak and strong lensing and dynamical data allowed <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2010b)</a> to disentangle the two effects, showing that the most likely explanation is that both the dark matter content and the normalization of the IMF increase with galaxy mass (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b22\" data-open=\"b22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Cardone et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b33\" data-open=\"b33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Grillo &amp; Gobat 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b51\" data-open=\"b51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tortora et al. 2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. 2011a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Thomas et al. 2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b27\" data-open=\"b27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Deason et al. 2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Future papers of this series (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b62\" data-open=\"b62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Barnab\u00e8 et al. 2012</a>; Dutton et al., in preparation) will combine the lensing information with dynamical models of kinematic observations to construct two component mass models and disentangle the luminous and dark components for the SWELLS sample as well (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b57\" data-open=\"b57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Trott et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">van de Ven et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Suyu et al. 2011</a>; Paper II). This will allow us to differentiate trends in the stellar IMF from trends in dark matter content over the entire range in velocity dispersion.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408897 id=\"92408897\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6>6\u2002SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper we have presented complete multiband <em>HST</em> imaging (including new images obtained as part of our cycle 18 <em>HST</em> programme, GO-12292) for the largest currently known sample of gravitational lens systems where the deflector is an inclined discy galaxy. The SWELLS sample consists to date of 20 secure lenses and six probable lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each secure lens and one probable lens, we have derived gravitational lens models based on a single isothermal ellipsoid deflector plus external shear. In addition we have used the multicolour <em>HST</em> imaging to estimate the stellar mass of the bulge and disc component of each deflector based on SPS models. We have used the two measurements of stellar and total mass within the critical curve to study the normalization of the stellar IMF for spiral lens galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our main conclusions can be summarized as follows.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"></p><ul class=\"bullet\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The ratio between stellar mass and total mass within the critical curve correlates with the velocity dispersion of the deflector galaxy. By combining the SWELLS sample with the SLACS sample of more massive early-type galaxies, we find that the trend extends between 160 and 350\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup>. This trend can be due to variations in the normalization of the stellar IMF and/or in non-baryonic dark matter content.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">At the low velocity dispersion end (below 230\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup>) the Salpeter IMF predicts, unphysically, that the mass in stars is greater than the total mass.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on a rigorous probabilistic model, we find that the probability that the true stellar masses are lighter than implied by the Salpeter IMF is 98 per\u2003cent for galaxies with velocity dispersion below 230\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup>, neglecting the contribution of cold gas. If the contribution of cold gas is taken into account, the probability increases to greater than 99 per\u2003cent, and a 95 per\u2003cent upper limit on the stellar masses is 80 per\u2003cent of the mass implied by the Salpeter IMF.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The light IMF required for low-mass spiral galaxies is at variance with the Salpeter or heavier IMF required for more massive early-type galaxies, consistent with a non-universal stellar IMF.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">AAD acknowledges financial support from a CITA National Fellowship, from the National Science Foundation Science and Technology Center CfAO, managed by UC Santa Cruz under cooperative agreement no. AST-9876783. AAD and DCK were partially supported by NSF grant AST 08-08133 and by <em>HST</em> grants AR-10664.01-A, HST AR-10965.02-A and HST GO-11206.02-A. PJM was given support by the TABASGO and Kavli foundations, and the Royal Society, in the form of research fellowships. TT acknowledges support from the NSF through CAREER award NSF-0642621, and from the Packard Foundation through a Packard Research Fellowship. LVEK acknowledges the support by an NWO-VIDI programme subsidy (programme number 639.042.505). This research is supported by NASA through <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> programmes GO-10587, GO-10886, GO-10174, 10494, 10798, 11202, 11978 and 12292, and in part by the National Science Foundation under grant no. PHY99-07949 and is based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> and obtained at the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555, and at the W. M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W. M. Keck Foundation. The authors wish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain. Funding for the SDSS and SDSS-II was provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the Participating Institutions, the National Science Foundation, the US Department of Energy, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Japanese Monbukagakusho, the Max Planck Society and the Higher Education Funding Council for England. The SDSS was managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions. The SDSS website is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss.org/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.sdss.org/</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408905 id=\"92408905\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"b1\" data-legacy-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Auger</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M.
