E.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n</span>, <div class=\"year\">2011</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">417</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1601</div> (Paper I)</p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/mnr.2011.417.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1111%2Fmnr.2011.417.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1111%2Fmnr.2011.417.issue-3\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b57\" data-legacy-id=\"b57\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b57\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b57\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b57\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Trott</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">C. M.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Treu</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Koopmans</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">L. V. E.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Webster</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R. L.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n</span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">401</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1540</div>\r\n</p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/mnr.2010.401.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1111%2Fmnr.2010.401.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1111%2Fmnr.2010.401.issue-3\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b58\" data-legacy-id=\"b58\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b58\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b58\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b58\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">van Albada</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T. S.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Sancisi</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n</span>, <div class=\"year\">1986</div>, <div class=\"source \">Philos. Trans. R. Soc. Series A</div>, <div class=\"volume\">320</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">447</div>\r\n</p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rsta.1986.0128\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1098%2Frsta.1986.0128\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1098%2Frsta.1986.0128\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b59\" data-legacy-id=\"b59\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b59\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b59\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b59\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">van de</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">Ven G.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Falc\u00f3n-Barroso</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">J.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">McDermid</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R. M.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Cappellari</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Miller</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">B. W.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">de Zeeuw</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">P. T.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n</span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">719</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1481</div>\r\n</p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/719/2/1481\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F719%2F2%2F1481\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F719%2F2%2F1481\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b61\" data-legacy-id=\"b61\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b61\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b61\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b61\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">van Dokkum</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">P. G.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Conroy</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">C.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n</span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">Nat</div>, <div class=\"volume\">468</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">940</div>\r\n</p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature09578\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1038%2Fnature09578\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1038%2Fnature09578\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408906 id=\"92408906\" class=\"backappendixgroup-title\" data-legacy-id=s3>Appendix</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92408907 id=\"92408907\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=ss9>APPENDIX A:\u2002COMPARISON OF LENS MODELS WITH PREVIOUS MODELS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The SWELLS sample contains six spiral lens galaxies that were originally discovered and modelled in SLACS. As a sanity check, we compare the inferred Einstein radii of these lenses from the models presented in this paper with those reported by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2009)</a>. Since <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2009)</a> reported Einstein radii in units of kiloparsecs, we convert our Einstein radii to kiloparsecs also. The comparison is shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. A1</a> and demonstrates agreement between the two sets of models.</p>                        <a id=\"92408909\" scrollto-destination=\"92408909\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=bJrXZ5-xFpfJqdmUnmZh9JG9pS1NiU8QPKp7NKEVP2SyWHwSvxMAvNQsq7tEAzJ5Y3EGy9m7oMf7EgiQB5rCOIcMzlaqsHNwWPlARZFh-aKCgUmeGZ3asL1rPj8qSSEJlxuQHo89jniLFV8yRAodtrN8Nb~BMtigMKFK61CBPwC-g3Wp~r2A5AjEAyHg8hOzSopDW8ZA0xawcVCGV9nhIMrySoR6VHess3KCkv1R~9m--CCHnJASSfKA9PO0Y6FZ7L3B4G50aCd8t8B3dEohhIzCgHy~bZApxFnOx337GKbXdHugMneNVS-PFVXADNq1D6XMg9LZx9RBP0uj41Kieg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A comparison of the inferred Einstein radii of lenses included in the SWELLS sample and the SLACS sample. Error bars were not reported by Auger et al. (2009). The solid line is the one-to-one relation. The inferred Einstein radii are consistent between the two studies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408909/mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408909\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=rj9kIjvRzV0CDzX~oEXNRoajqWzrf8CiH1qIzaHwoe5RXQW5iiuOC83RoBiOe1tjj3Jk8pdSw8gLlWL3v2gPEADTcKZgsSB18kkVtNs6nHe7ml1gPdZ-38Ccv1z6SCq3hsOZQfyoGzi69oHphYGGxNZqi8l8MlHs4LV9DDtqRSc~CHo3nIvPTqF3mVEmav4Uj2korGOoTiU1423pMwpbdMq8fzdaEGCYtcvIB2wjELNMK4QTMb36uYNeUEvPL5gBTE-FwH6OGBIb-JhIbXeQc1OE8yc-RxcXoyUktwFsVtFN3PEc-sVB0twG8~5yTrP-UL7fITdPZAA~RawY~RnrMw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408909&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A comparison of the inferred Einstein radii of lenses included in the SWELLS sample and the SLACS sample. Error bars were not reported by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2009)</a>. The solid line is the one-to-one relation. The inferred Einstein radii are consistent between the two studies.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=bJrXZ5-xFpfJqdmUnmZh9JG9pS1NiU8QPKp7NKEVP2SyWHwSvxMAvNQsq7tEAzJ5Y3EGy9m7oMf7EgiQB5rCOIcMzlaqsHNwWPlARZFh-aKCgUmeGZ3asL1rPj8qSSEJlxuQHo89jniLFV8yRAodtrN8Nb~BMtigMKFK61CBPwC-g3Wp~r2A5AjEAyHg8hOzSopDW8ZA0xawcVCGV9nhIMrySoR6VHess3KCkv1R~9m--CCHnJASSfKA9PO0Y6FZ7L3B4G50aCd8t8B3dEohhIzCgHy~bZApxFnOx337GKbXdHugMneNVS-PFVXADNq1D6XMg9LZx9RBP0uj41Kieg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A comparison of the inferred Einstein radii of lenses included in the SWELLS sample and the SLACS sample. Error bars were not reported by Auger et al. (2009). The solid line is the one-to-one relation. The inferred Einstein radii are consistent between the two studies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408909/mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408909\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=rj9kIjvRzV0CDzX~oEXNRoajqWzrf8CiH1qIzaHwoe5RXQW5iiuOC83RoBiOe1tjj3Jk8pdSw8gLlWL3v2gPEADTcKZgsSB18kkVtNs6nHe7ml1gPdZ-38Ccv1z6SCq3hsOZQfyoGzi69oHphYGGxNZqi8l8MlHs4LV9DDtqRSc~CHo3nIvPTqF3mVEmav4Uj2korGOoTiU1423pMwpbdMq8fzdaEGCYtcvIB2wjELNMK4QTMb36uYNeUEvPL5gBTE-FwH6OGBIb-JhIbXeQc1OE8yc-RxcXoyUktwFsVtFN3PEc-sVB0twG8~5yTrP-UL7fITdPZAA~RawY~RnrMw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408909&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A comparison of the inferred Einstein radii of lenses included in the SWELLS sample and the SLACS sample. Error bars were not reported by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2009)</a>. The solid line is the one-to-one relation. The inferred Einstein radii are consistent between the two studies.</p></div></div>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel Column 1 lists the lens ID; columns 2 and 3 the coordinates (J2000 in degrees); columns 4 and 5 give deflector and source redshifts; column 6 the Einstein radius of the lens model; column 7 the velocity dispersion of the SIE plus external shear (SIE+\u03b3) lens model; column 8 the axis ratio of the lens model; column 9 the projected mass within the critical curve of the SIE lens model; columns 10 and 11 the ratio between the stellar mass and lensing mass within the critical curve, assuming Chabrier and Salpeter IMF, respectively; column 12 is the reference for the lens discovery (1 = B06, 2 = B08, 3 = Paper I, 4 = this paper); column 13 is the band used for the lens modelling.</p></div></div><div js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\n          Open in new tab\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of basic properties of modelled grade \u2018A\u2019 lenses (plus the modelled grade \u2018B\u2019 lens J1422+4134) from the SWELLS sample of spiral lens galaxies. Column 1 lists the lens ID; columns 2 and 3 the coordinates (J2000 in degrees); columns 4 and 5 give deflector and source redshifts; column 6 the Einstein radius of the lens model; column 7 the velocity dispersion of the SIE plus external shear (SIE+\u03b3) lens model; column 8 the axis ratio of the lens model; column 9 the projected mass within the critical curve of the SIE lens model; columns 10 and 11 the ratio between the stellar mass and lensing mass within the critical curve, assuming Chabrier and Salpeter IMF, respectively; column 12 is the reference for the lens discovery (1 = B06, 2 = B08, 3 = Paper I, 4 = this paper); column 13 is the band used for the lens modelling.</p></div></div><div Koopmans\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search-label\">\r\n        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-internal\">\r\n    <a href=\"/mnras/search-results?f_Authors=L%c3%a9on+V.+E.+Koopmans\">Oxford Academic</a>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-google\">\r\n        <a href=\"http://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=author:%22Koopmans L&#233;on V. E.%22\">Google Scholar</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search info-card-search-ads\">\r\n        <a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-abs_connect?return_req=no_params&amp;author=Koopmans,L\">ADS</a>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>                                    </span>\r\n                                </span>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n<div class=\"pub-history-wrap clearfix\">\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"pub-history-row clearfix\">\r\n            <div class=\"ww-citation-primary\"><em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 422, Issue 4, June 2012, Pages 3574\u20133590, <a   <li class=\"toolbar-item item-pdf\">\r\n        <a class=\"al-link pdf article-pdfLink\" data-article-id=\"1055422\" href=\"/mnras/article-pdf/422/4/3574/18608510/mnras0422-3574.pdf\">\r\n            <img src=//oup.silverchair-cdn.com/UI/app/svg/pdf.svg alt=\"pdf\" /><span class=\"pdf-link-text\">PDF</span>\r\n        </a>\r\n    </li>\r\n                                                    <li class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down               <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a Disfavouring \u2018heavy\u2019 initial mass functions for spiral lens galaxies, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 422, Issue 4, June 2012, Pages 3574\u20133590, <a <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input     <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408729 id=\"92408729\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present gravitational lens models for 20 strong gravitational lens systems observed as part of the Sloan WFC Edge-on Late-type Lens Survey (SWELLS) project. 15 of the lenses are taken from Paper I, while five are newly discovered systems. The systems are galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses where the foreground deflector has an inclined disc, with a wide range of morphological types, from late-type spiral to lenticular. For each system, we compare the total mass inside the critical curve inferred from gravitational lens modelling to the stellar mass inferred from stellar population synthesis (SPS) models, computing the stellar mass fraction <em>f</em>*\u2261<em>M</em><sub>SPS</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>lens</sub>. We find that, for the lower mass SWELLS systems, adoption of a Salpeter stellar initial mass function (IMF) leads to estimates of <em>f</em>* that exceed 1. This is unphysical and provides strong evidence against the Salpeter IMF being valid for these systems. Taking the lower mass end of the SWELLS sample (\u03c3<sub>SIE</sub> &lt; 230\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup>), we find that the IMF is lighter (in terms of stellar mass-to-light ratio) than Salpeter with 98 per\u2003cent probability, and consistent with the Chabrier IMF and IMFs between the two. This result is consistent with previous studies of spiral galaxies based on independent techniques. In combination with recent studies of massive early-type galaxies that have favoured a heavier Salpeter-like IMF, this result strengthens the evidence against a universal stellar IMF.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;stars: luminosity function, mass function&quot;\">stars: luminosity function, mass function</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: fundamental parameters&quot;\">galaxies: fundamental parameters</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: spiral&quot;\">galaxies: spiral</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408731 id=\"92408731\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss1>1\u2002INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The stellar initial mass function (IMF) is a fundamental property of a simple stellar population and plays a key role in many astrophysical problems. For instance, the determination of galaxy stellar masses and star formation rates are uncertain at the factor of \u223c2 level due to uncertainty in the IMF (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Panter et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Conroy, Gunn &amp; White 2009</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observations of the solar neighbourhood favour an IMF with a power-law slope at high masses (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b44\" data-open=\"b44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Salpeter 1955</a>) and a turnover at low masses (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b38\" data-open=\"b38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kroupa 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b23\" data-open=\"b23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Chabrier 2003</a>). While other spiral galaxies have IMFs consistent with that of the Milky Way (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bell &amp; de Jong 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bershady et al. 2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. 2011a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Suyu et al. 2011</a>), there is increasing evidence from a variety of observations that the IMF is non-universal. Specifically, massive early-type galaxies at low redshifts require IMFs that are heavier than in the Milky Way (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2010b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b47\" data-open=\"b47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sonnenfeld et al. 2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b48\" data-open=\"b48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Spiniello et al. 2011</a>), and possibly heavier than Salpeter in the most massive ellipticals (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b61\" data-open=\"b61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">van Dokkum &amp; Conroy 2010</a>). Other lensing and dynamical studies of early-type galaxies also suggest that the IMF may be heavy (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Thomas et al. 2011</a>) although these observations may also be explained by a trend in the properties of the dark matter haloes. Recently, variations in the IMF of early-type galaxies have also been reported by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b21\" data-open=\"b21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Cappellari et al. (2012)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton, Mendel &amp; Simard (2012)</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">One of the simplest ways of constraining the galaxy-averaged IMF is through comparing total masses (within some aperture), as derived by kinematics and/or strong gravitational lensing and referred to as gravitational masses henceforth, with stellar masses derived from stellar population synthesis (SPS) models (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Cappellari et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ferreras et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Thomas et al. 2011</a>). While this method typically only provides strong upper limits to the stellar mass due to the unknown dark matter fraction, as well as the unknown mass in gas, dust, etc., the upper limits are robust.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Dark matter fractions in galaxies are expected to increase with radius, so the strongest constraints on the IMF (from total mass measurements) come from measuring mass-to-light ratios at small galactic radii. However, at small radii, kinematics are harder to interpret, as there is usually a mix of rotation and dispersion. This is where strong gravitational lensing is particularly useful and unique, because it measures projected mass independent of the dynamical state of the deflector.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Assuming a universal IMF, the dark matter fractions within the effective radius of early-type galaxies decrease with decreasing mass (down to a stellar mass of \u224310<sup>10</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>) (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b41\" data-open=\"b41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Padmanabhan et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b32\" data-open=\"b32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gallazzi et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2010a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Barnab\u00e8 et al. 2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. 2011a</a>). Thus lower mass elliptical galaxies are expected to place stronger constraints on the IMF than higher mass elliptical galaxies (although high-mass systems can place strong constraints as well through dynamics; e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b48\" data-open=\"b48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Spiniello et al. 2011</a>). If the bulges of spiral galaxies follow the same scaling relations as elliptical galaxies, then we would expect that bulges of mass \u224310<sup>10</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2013 where the dark matter fraction is minimized \u2013 would provide the strongest constraints on the IMF if the IMF is universal (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b8\" data-open=\"b8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bastian, Covey &amp; Meyer 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kroupa et al. 2011</a>). Conversely, if the IMF is not universal, measuring it as a function of galaxy mass, morphology and environment should help understand the physical mechanisms that determine it.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measuring the absolute normalization of stellar IMF as a function of galaxy type and mass is one of the main goals of the Sloan WFC Edge-on Late-type Lens Survey (SWELLS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b56\" data-open=\"b56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu et al. 2011</a>, hereafter Paper I; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. 2011b</a>, hereafter Paper II).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) multicolour imaging of the complete SWELLS sample, including new data from cycle 18 observations, and use strong lensing models to constrain the stellar IMF of spiral galaxies. In particular, we use precision measurements of the total mass within the critical curve and therefore place an upper limit on the amount of stellar mass. We combine this inferences with stellar masses derived from SPS models to obtain strong upper limits on the normalization of the stellar IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The galaxies in the SWELLS sample have total stellar masses (assuming a Chabrier IMF) of <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u2243 4\u201330 \u00d7 10<sup>10</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub> and bulge masses of \u22432\u201310 \u00d7 10<sup>10</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub> (Paper I). In order to explore the variation of the IMF with stellar mass, we combine our sample with the more massive elliptical galaxy lenses from the Sloan Lens ACS (Advanced Camera for Surveys) Survey (SLACS) (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>) with <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u2243 10\u201350 \u00d7 10<sup>10</sup>\u2003M<sub>\u2299</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Throughout this paper, we assume a flat \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) cosmology with present-day matter density, \u03a9<sub>m</sub>= 0.3, and Hubble parameter, <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>= 70\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2003Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408747 id=\"92408747\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2>2\u2002THE DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section we briefly summarize the sample selection procedure (Section 2.1; more details can be found in Paper I) and then present the new cycle 18 <em>HST</em> observations in Section 2.2.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92408750 id=\"92408750\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-1>2.1\u2002Sample selection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The sample of spiral lens galaxy candidates was selected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) data base as discussed in Paper I. Briefly, the spectroscopic data base was searched for composite spectra, consisting of foreground spectrum superimposed with multiple emission lines at a higher redshifts, following the procedures developed for the SLACS (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b13\" data-open=\"b13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bolton et al. 2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b14\" data-open=\"b14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, hereafter B06 and B08, respectively) and the BOSS (Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey) Emission-Line Lensing Survey (BELLS; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brownstein et al. 2012</a>) surveys. In addition, however, in order to identify inclined late-type galaxies suitable for rotation curve measurements, the deflector galaxies were selected to have axis ratios <em>q</em>=<em>b</em>/<em>a</em>\u2272 0.6 with a preference for galaxies with edge-on discs and emission lines indicating star formation. A priori lensing probabilities were estimated based on the SDSS stellar velocity dispersion and stellar Einstein radius (Paper I).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92408758 id=\"92408758\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-2>2.2\u2002<em>HST</em> observations and surface photometry</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The highest probability lens candidates were followed up with <em>HST</em> in supplemental cycle 16s programme (GO-11978; PI: Treu) and are presented in Paper I. In addition, during the same programme, multiband imaging was obtained for disc lens galaxies identified as part of the SLACS survey (GOs 10174, 10494, 10798, 11202, PI: Koopmans; GOs 10587, 10886, PI: Bolton). Lower probability systems were included in a cycle 18 programme (GO-12292; PI: Treu), aiming to extend the sample to later type spirals, and are presented here for the first time. Two candidates confirmed from the ground with adaptive optics (AO; Paper I) were also included in the cycle 18 programme to collect optical multiband photometry. 21 candidates were observed in cycle 18. 18 of those were observed with the refurbished Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) for one orbit each, split equally between filters <em>F435W</em> and <em>F814W</em>. Two dithered exposures were obtained for each filter to aid in cosmic ray and defect removal and to help improve the sampling of the point spread function (PSF). Four candidates, including one observed with ACS were observed with the infrared channel of the Wide Field Camera 3 for a full orbit through filter <em>F160W</em>. Each orbit was split into four dithered exposures to aid in cosmic ray and defect removal and help improve the sampling of the PSF. The <em>HST</em> images were reduced using standard multidrizzle techniques. As expected, the fraction of grade \u2018A\u2019 and \u2018B\u2019 lenses was lower for cycle 18 than for previous cycles, 6/21 and 10/21, respectively; images for these 21 systems are displayed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92408764\" scrollto-destination=\"92408764\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f1.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=JKnOcWGm7vNlueAFC4W0E1~ZGiNwvRNeEoh88IyYf9H4qYJeJDkdZ9wO7AEL16MHGQ3~uBn23sPpnmZsx9Y2u8OdDisMN52qb26kfel1GeSepkYjdYmKJWDROFgNfAgA3NLiJ26rpMpc~Bqm3UKtUsCGnLr4paXt5hiR7nZytDxOT5Fhr0TprrI6zQFDoCMavSCK1vppuFbjBsUaTQEYzs07~ypa-tklG2Yah205CIt9RuKQJNrivV3M~~FhUR4khi3mEDNJS1Z2MGnmPswXPLA8YhR93sb23pQ1hZ669XItOdzP6ecizmI9IkAHPQDzgEoyt3X1pJPPZxDzt0MHhg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Images of the 21 candidate lens systems observed with the HST during cycle 18; the grade of each system is provided in parentheses next to the name.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f1.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=JKnOcWGm7vNlueAFC4W0E1~ZGiNwvRNeEoh88IyYf9H4qYJeJDkdZ9wO7AEL16MHGQ3~uBn23sPpnmZsx9Y2u8OdDisMN52qb26kfel1GeSepkYjdYmKJWDROFgNfAgA3NLiJ26rpMpc~Bqm3UKtUsCGnLr4paXt5hiR7nZytDxOT5Fhr0TprrI6zQFDoCMavSCK1vppuFbjBsUaTQEYzs07~ypa-tklG2Yah205CIt9RuKQJNrivV3M~~FhUR4khi3mEDNJS1Z2MGnmPswXPLA8YhR93sb23pQ1hZ669XItOdzP6ecizmI9IkAHPQDzgEoyt3X1pJPPZxDzt0MHhg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Images of the 21 candidate lens systems observed with the HST during cycle 18; the grade of each system is provided in parentheses next to the name.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408764/mnras0422-3574-f1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408764\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f1.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=tmJLa1s7F1ZlvnkXkiffp4nHU~Dkfiee7n5pNOF3fugmKhDxc8lKDTLZD5Bp7id4k9v7dqXp-TkoxCtEmGtaKzRDG7xpzH-q5wDlxesVcCye0bxloDZreX2f0acoUe~pF0odGOwKnwvkrq86Gnh6jKReQvC-tlgCh9CQCM8upqCS4gzxlHYZYYCVrrqVwqM2XKqKbTown17Y7VqKis9aClCYl1lI2YCb4tuRYZCeWIJ-TWqpPNhugWJkRZIy7BJ~9L243PrTDWPdCRf5sPm6u3bLiZy6GL6EWY9DQCCDwZJnGnk9SoDq5mZ7IoiEUwNHeOht2N6kNLs5KGARKXij-A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408764&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Images of the 21 candidate lens systems observed with the <em>HST</em> during cycle 18; the grade of each system is provided in parentheses next to the name.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In total, after <em>HST</em> imaging, the SWELLS sample consists of 20 secure lenses (grade \u2018A\u2019), six probable lenses (grade \u2018B\u2019) and 12 possible lenses (grade \u2018C\u2019). Grade \u2018A\u2019 lenses are defined as having unambiguous multiple images successfully reproduced by a reasonably simple lens model. Grade \u2018B\u2019 lenses are defined as having evidence for strong lensing, even though the quality of the data is not sufficient to identify unambiguously multiple images and/or construct a lens model. This definition is quite conservative and we expect that with deeper data or narrow-band imaging data to facilitate removal of the foreground deflector light, most \u2018B\u2019 grade systems would be confirmed as lenses. Grade \u2018C\u2019 are possible lenses where we expect that even with significantly better data only a minority of the systems would be confirmed as lenses. A colour montage of the 20 grade \u2018A\u2019 lenses from SWELLS is shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f2\" data-open=\"f2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92408769\" scrollto-destination=\"92408769\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" lens systems that comprise the SWELLS sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f2.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=2DZRck~jL-bYRz2GMAtL1oY2jyI2xLIWX3biz-owJYiguVVyIqcDJ5-QimIemiSCUvdMOGw4p46bRyGkqWYSxuT8B2wtv9jy9~7qWl3-VBIpXmcm103EOSLD--uJd~r868vb0mSwIbqepUsp5qtKbTcHrcSNYQX9fFdsM-iTDtynprbQJ-pROdBV6i2JxZqKfzwf1l3icEcH064E8AjD2DaViGusm4Gzg9jYMViybeZzMytAlKLGEpApApUx3sbYVuXXQsF2744~vxPXi22NKWA1xX34uPz6A7elmTjy6EpSfAPK3N81ECpnA8HuBGH6xWoInVp55GPHlKYvNvTCkg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Images of the 20 grade \u2018A\u2019 lens systems that comprise the SWELLS sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408769/mnras0422-3574-f2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408769\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f2.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=Q41XwphkoZ1-sh8t63nfxw31Y64M0Z3FREAordfRWWIjMkAJc7Hj6iErT7~xqbvdi6TYjF9pNIxh37~DA9moBzpwkcLHkzMrc2Vo0Pw1uzFgqYjawD-axS3RgnoOJEviJkHzQasW~YAxi2xs6NZGs54851fk7YElHE~E95InE4KN5lJzB7EcX6YWRcy0p4PecZb3-qA5W9Grv84~SkCuT6ssr3EUu5dUSP36hsM8Q69QgXLjfLNrnpqhB-7Cab44lrB~BaaHR58EgLffD-h5WswOBmCT02VozUQ1wBwlJ1n37C8qEVRmScL4kraHA9qGwIROwTsgUJieXlqZ7Jb5rQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408769&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Images of the 20 grade \u2018A\u2019 lens systems that comprise the SWELLS sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For this paper we focus our analysis on the grade \u2018A\u2019 lenses, plus one grade \u2018B\u2019 lens (J1422+4134), for which we were able to obtain a plausible lens model. However, in the light of the uncertain identification of this one system, we will use only the grade \u2018A\u2019 lenses for our inference on the stellar IMF. We also excluded one grade \u2018A\u2019 lens, J1037+3517, since the morphology of the lens is complex (involving a merger) and the modelling approach of this paper was unlikely to be successful for this system. A summary of the basic properties of the SWELLS lenses together with the inferred parameters of the gravitational lens models is given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>. A summary of the basic properties of the SWELLS <em>HST</em> cycle 18 targets is given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92408775\" scrollto-destination=\"92408775\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of basic properties of modelled grade \u2018A\u2019 lenses (plus the modelled grade \u2018B\u2019 lens J1422+4134) from the SWELLS sample of spiral lens galaxies. Column 1 lists the lens ID; columns 2 and 3 the coordinates (J2000 in degrees); columns 4 and 5 give deflector and source redshifts; column 6 the Einstein radius of the lens model; column 7 the velocity dispersion of the SIE plus external shear (SIE+\u03b3) lens model; column 8 the axis ratio of the lens model; column 9 the projected mass within the critical curve of the SIE lens model; columns 10 and 11 the ratio between the stellar mass and lensing mass within the critical curve, assuming Chabrier and Salpeter IMF, respectively; column 12 is the reference for the lens discovery (1 = B06, 2 = B08, 3 = Paper I, 4 = this paper); column 13 is the band used for the lens modelling.</p></div></div><div js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92408775\">\n          Open in new tab\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of basic properties of modelled grade \u2018A\u2019 lenses (plus the modelled grade \u2018B\u2019 lens J1422+4134) from the SWELLS sample of spiral lens galaxies. Column 1 lists the lens ID; columns 2 and 3 the coordinates (J2000 in degrees); columns 4 and 5 give deflector and source redshifts; column 6 the Einstein radius of the lens model; column 7 the velocity dispersion of the SIE plus external shear (SIE+\u03b3) lens model; column 8 the axis ratio of the lens model; column 9 the projected mass within the critical curve of the SIE lens model; columns 10 and 11 the ratio between the stellar mass and lensing mass within the critical curve, assuming Chabrier and Salpeter IMF, respectively; column 12 is the reference for the lens discovery (1 = B06, 2 = B08, 3 = Paper I, 4 = this paper); column 13 is the band used for the lens modelling.</p></div></div><div data-id=\"t2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of basic properties of the SWELLS <em>HST</em> cycle 18 targets. class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of basic properties of the SWELLS <em>HST</em> cycle 18 targets. Column 1 lists the lens ID; columns 2 and 3 the coordinates (J2000 in degrees); columns 4 and 5 give deflector and source redshifts; column 6 the lens grade (A = secure, B = probable, C = possible and class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92408779\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiband surface photometry was derived as described in Paper I, by fitting two-component (bulge+disc) models using <span class=\"small-caps\">spasmoid</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bennert et al. 2011</a>). The model consists of an <em>n</em>= 4 S\u00e9rsic profile (i.e. a de Vaucouleurs profile; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b26\" data-open=\"b26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">de Vaucouleurs 1948</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">S\u00e9rsic 1968</a>) for the bulge and an <em>n</em>= 1 exponential disc component. Estimates of the model parameters, including stellar masses and mass-to-light ratios, are given in Tables 3\u20135.</p>                        <a id=\"92408782\" scrollto-destination=\"92408782\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t3\" data-id=\"t3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Structure of SWELLS <em>HST</em> cycle 18 targets with multiband imaging. Column 1 lists the lens ID; columns 2\u20139 the AB magnitudes of the bulge and the disc in the various bands; column 10 circularized half-light radius of the bulge; column 11 the axis ratio of the bulge; column 12 circularized half-light radius of the disc; column 13 the axis ratio of the disc. The stellar masses inferred from these magnitudes are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t4\" data-open=\"t4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Structure of SWELLS <em>HST</em> cycle 18 targets with multiband imaging. Column 1 lists the lens ID; columns 2\u20139 the AB magnitudes of the bulge and the disc in the various bands; column 10 circularized half-light radius of the bulge; column 11 the axis ratio of the bulge; column 12 circularized half-light radius of the disc; column 13 the axis ratio of the disc.
