The value of \u03c3 is constrained to be low (&lt;0.16 with 95 per\u2003cent probability), so there is evidence that the intrinsic stellar mass fractions are fairly homogeneous across the low-mass end of the SWELLS sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408885/mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408885\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=fKOza33dNP0OM-0yAELxrevcfZUNgFR~sY4DIBXTBkhzhNrjV4b2kaSc2ehBMS8Rpv0PZGtZh1VgE0zWA4Mdoj9FSx5WBzPknkrGOZNBAyhS-S8hRvoJjkqTJB9bd~IiRpnj2aXzQbo803y493nir43BnMg2yL5NPNU6yZ2pxdzgP1whnr0FAgqwx4Gjqaa6iEh69IwDgTOOk01gNR4xA4XvfQbj2EqHCk-4Uy6Fc3R-tMXMYbNZ0WrKfhejorugTlHTCGpHz9h6jg6Gr-hdQwyelPJIvkJ1U1TKbsZ~qXAYsavV7V8olHIrZr4OpOh0UkOzHFdM-3zV7LRaqxJM1g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408885&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inference on the parameter \u03c3, the intrinsic scatter in the true distribution of stellar mass fractions <em>F</em>*. The value of \u03c3 is constrained to be low (&lt;0.16 with 95 per\u2003cent probability), so there is evidence that the intrinsic stellar mass fractions are fairly homogeneous across the low-mass end of the SWELLS sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=aGJ0RPpcml34~sDRyoJKGv5ayhHreMy5iQZ5RzqnaTcMUjux2dwSNJJW-1GCajJnddChshggefI8kD~2FpliUISxZS0txcWkOIXb-M1pdDPwCTwJmIJaqVxLrOdGw6GYIosP~U~-LjPhEFXMIZLGlax~aCLjbg-sebKzMfuPXsrpRoGy5AlxJ3dOdGPb3LxZMf6795tncbZ4TorNXiYlsIp7xOdEn27cfrzCNQ6IRFKSTcYNZLJEClh7GGRIcyKjd-t0ymodG~RG49MrDX~Y18MOqIkK-Vodw~g1-sId445KI9mAyhDZmTP3fnE8yjs09Am8SMQOqtYuSTo82zLmjA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Inference on the parameter \u03c3, the intrinsic scatter in the true distribution of stellar mass fractions F*. The value of \u03c3 is constrained to be low (&lt;0.16 with 95 per\u2003cent probability), so there is evidence that the intrinsic stellar mass fractions are fairly homogeneous across the low-mass end of the SWELLS sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408885/mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408885\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=fKOza33dNP0OM-0yAELxrevcfZUNgFR~sY4DIBXTBkhzhNrjV4b2kaSc2ehBMS8Rpv0PZGtZh1VgE0zWA4Mdoj9FSx5WBzPknkrGOZNBAyhS-S8hRvoJjkqTJB9bd~IiRpnj2aXzQbo803y493nir43BnMg2yL5NPNU6yZ2pxdzgP1whnr0FAgqwx4Gjqaa6iEh69IwDgTOOk01gNR4xA4XvfQbj2EqHCk-4Uy6Fc3R-tMXMYbNZ0WrKfhejorugTlHTCGpHz9h6jg6Gr-hdQwyelPJIvkJ1U1TKbsZ~qXAYsavV7V8olHIrZr4OpOh0UkOzHFdM-3zV7LRaqxJM1g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408885&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Inference on the parameter \u03c3, the intrinsic scatter in the true distribution of stellar mass fractions <em>F</em>*. The value of \u03c3 is constrained to be low (&lt;0.16 with 95 per\u2003cent probability), so there is evidence that the intrinsic stellar mass fractions are fairly homogeneous across the low-mass end of the SWELLS sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Note that, if we take into account the fact that there can be an additional 20 per\u2003cent of mass in cold gas distributed in the same way as the stars (as in Papers II), the probability that the IMF is lighter than Salpeter becomes greater than 99 per\u2003cent. Correspondingly, the 95 per\u2003cent probability upper limit to \u03b1 becomes 0.80.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408887 id=\"92408887\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5>5\u2002DISCUSSION AND COMPARISON WITH PREVIOUS WORK</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The main result of this paper is that the stellar mass of spiral galaxies with lens velocity dispersion between 160 and 230\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup> (i.e. with masses comparable to or slightly above the Milky Way) is lighter than that predicted based on their colours using a Salpeter IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This conclusion is based on a robust and straightforward argument, i.e. the stellar mass cannot exceed the total mass measured by strong gravitational lensing. A high abundance of cold gas would make our result even stronger, requiring even less mass in stars and therefore a lighter normalization of the IMF. Systematic uncertainties in the stellar mass estimates due to differences in SPS models and assumptions are of the order of 0.05\u20130.1\u2003dex for a fixed IMF (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Conroy et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu et al. 2010</a>) and therefore not sufficient to modify our conclusions significantly.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Even though our sample is the largest sample of spiral lens galaxies currently available, it is important to consider whether this result could somehow be biased by unknown selection effects. In Paper I we investigated the selection function in detail by comparing the size mass relation of SWELLS lenses to that of non-lens galaxies selected from SDSS and found them to be statistically equivalent. The detailed analysis of the lens SDSS J2141\u22120001 presented in Paper II indicates that that galaxy might be drawn from the densest part of the distribution of mass density profiles of spiral galaxies. Whether this is a generic feature of lensing selection needs to be verified by the detailed analysis of the entire sample. However, if lens galaxies were representative of the densest spiral galaxies, this would only make our inference stronger with respect to the overall population, since the densest galaxies are likely those with the highest stellar content.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our results are consistent with independent estimates of the normalization of the stellar IMF of spiral galaxies based on a variety of techniques. For example, based on spiral galaxy rotation curves, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bell &amp; de Jong (2001)</a> find that a Salpeter IMF is too heavy and argue for a normalization that is significantly lower. Based on the vertical velocity dispersion of discs, the Disc Mass Survey (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bershady et al. 2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) argues that the mass-to-light ratio (and hence the normalization of the stellar IMF) is significantly lower than that inferred assuming a Salpeter IMF. Interestingly, a qualitatively similar result is found for elliptical galaxies in the same velocity dispersion range. Dynamical arguments (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Cappellari et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. 2012</a>) as well as joint dynamical and lensing arguments (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Barnab\u00e8 et al. 2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) show that a Salpeter IMF is too heavy for low-mass ellipticals.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The light normalization of the stellar IMF (or equivalently mass-to-light ratio) required for spirals and ellipticals comparable to the mass of the Milky Way is in contrast to the heavier normalization required for more massive systems. For example, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b61\" data-open=\"b61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">van Dokkum &amp; Conroy (2010)</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b48\" data-open=\"b48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Spiniello et al. (2011)</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2010b)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b47\" data-open=\"b47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sonnenfeld et al. (2011)</a>, using different techniques and data sets, find that light Chabrier-like IMFs are ruled out for the most massive early-type galaxies, and a heavier IMF is preferred. Further evidence for this hypothesis is provided by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Treu et al. (2010)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Thomas et al. (2011)</a>\u2013 and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Newman et al. (2011)</a> for the case of massive brightest cluster galaxies \u2013 although those studies could not break completely the degeneracy between dark matter content and normalization of the IMF.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Taken together, these results are consistent with the hypothesis that the stellar IMF is not universal, but that it changes systematically with galaxy stellar velocity dispersion and mass (and therefore halo mass to first approximation). Since stellar velocity dispersion correlates with the age of the stellar populations, this non-universality might reflect the non-universality of the conditions that were prevalent when the stars were formed. The obvious suspects are the density of the gas and the condition of ambient background radiation. A key open question is whether this variation in the IMF can be understood theoretically based on first principles.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is important to emphasize that lensing and dynamical measurements constrain the total normalization of the IMF and not its specific form. Therefore, by themselves they cannot constrain the shape of the IMF and reveal whether the change in the normalization is due to a change in the abundance of low-mass stars or remnants of high-mass stars or any combination thereof. Independent constraints such as those from stellar population diagnostics or from galaxies at different redshifts probing different ranges in stellar mass are necessary to break this degeneracy in the interpretation of the trend.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A final issue that we have not addressed in this paper is how much of the trend shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a> is due to a varying IMF and how much is due to varying dark matter content. For the higher velocity dispersion SLACS galaxies weak and strong lensing and dynamical data allowed <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2010b)</a> to disentangle the two effects, showing that the most likely explanation is that both the dark matter content and the normalization of the IMF increase with galaxy mass (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b22\" data-open=\"b22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Cardone et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b33\" data-open=\"b33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Grillo &amp; Gobat 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b51\" data-open=\"b51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tortora et al. 2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dutton et al. 2011a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Thomas et al. 2011</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b27\" data-open=\"b27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Deason et al. 2012</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Future papers of this series (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b62\" data-open=\"b62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Barnab\u00e8 et al. 2012</a>; Dutton et al., in preparation) will combine the lensing information with dynamical models of kinematic observations to construct two component mass models and disentangle the luminous and dark components for the SWELLS sample as well (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b57\" data-open=\"b57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Trott et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">van de Ven et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Suyu et al. 2011</a>; Paper II). This will allow us to differentiate trends in the stellar IMF from trends in dark matter content over the entire range in velocity dispersion.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408897 id=\"92408897\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss6>6\u2002SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper we have presented complete multiband <em>HST</em> imaging (including new images obtained as part of our cycle 18 <em>HST</em> programme, GO-12292) for the largest currently known sample of gravitational lens systems where the deflector is an inclined discy galaxy. The SWELLS sample consists to date of 20 secure lenses and six probable lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each secure lens and one probable lens, we have derived gravitational lens models based on a single isothermal ellipsoid deflector plus external shear. In addition we have used the multicolour <em>HST</em> imaging to estimate the stellar mass of the bulge and disc component of each deflector based on SPS models. We have used the two measurements of stellar and total mass within the critical curve to study the normalization of the stellar IMF for spiral lens galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our main conclusions can be summarized as follows.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"></p><ul class=\"bullet\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The ratio between stellar mass and total mass within the critical curve correlates with the velocity dispersion of the deflector galaxy. By combining the SWELLS sample with the SLACS sample of more massive early-type galaxies, we find that the trend extends between 160 and 350\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup>. This trend can be due to variations in the normalization of the stellar IMF and/or in non-baryonic dark matter content.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">At the low velocity dispersion end (below 230\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup>) the Salpeter IMF predicts, unphysically, that the mass in stars is greater than the total mass.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on a rigorous probabilistic model, we find that the probability that the true stellar masses are lighter than implied by the Salpeter IMF is 98 per\u2003cent for galaxies with velocity dispersion below 230\u2003km\u2003s<sup>\u22121</sup>, neglecting the contribution of cold gas. If the contribution of cold gas is taken into account, the probability increases to greater than 99 per\u2003cent, and a 95 per\u2003cent upper limit on the stellar masses is 80 per\u2003cent of the mass implied by the Salpeter IMF.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The light IMF required for low-mass spiral galaxies is at variance with the Salpeter or heavier IMF required for more massive early-type galaxies, consistent with a non-universal stellar IMF.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">AAD acknowledges financial support from a CITA National Fellowship, from the National Science Foundation Science and Technology Center CfAO, managed by UC Santa Cruz under cooperative agreement no. AST-9876783. AAD and DCK were partially supported by NSF grant AST 08-08133 and by <em>HST</em> grants AR-10664.01-A, HST AR-10965.02-A and HST GO-11206.02-A. PJM was given support by the TABASGO and Kavli foundations, and the Royal Society, in the form of research fellowships. TT acknowledges support from the NSF through CAREER award NSF-0642621, and from the Packard Foundation through a Packard Research Fellowship. LVEK acknowledges the support by an NWO-VIDI programme subsidy (programme number 639.042.505). This research is supported by NASA through <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> programmes GO-10587, GO-10886, GO-10174, 10494, 10798, 11202, 11978 and 12292, and in part by the National Science Foundation under grant no. PHY99-07949 and is based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> and obtained at the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555, and at the W. M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W. M. Keck Foundation. The authors wish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain. Funding for the SDSS and SDSS-II was provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the Participating Institutions, the National Science Foundation, the US Department of Energy, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the Japanese Monbukagakusho, the Max Planck Society and the Higher Education Funding Council for England. The SDSS was managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions. The SDSS website is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss.org/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.sdss.org/</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408905 id=\"92408905\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"b1\" data-legacy-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Auger</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M. E.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n</span>, <div class=\"year\">2011</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">417</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1601</div> (Paper I)</p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/mnr.2011.417.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1111%2Fmnr.2011.417.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1111%2Fmnr.2011.417.issue-3\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b57\" data-legacy-id=\"b57\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b57\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b57\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b57\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Trott</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">C. M.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Treu</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Koopmans</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">L. V. E.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Webster</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R. L.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n</span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">401</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1540</div>\r\n</p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/mnr.2010.401.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1111%2Fmnr.2010.401.issue-3\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1111%2Fmnr.2010.401.issue-3\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b58\" data-legacy-id=\"b58\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b58\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b58\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b58\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">van Albada</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T. S.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Sancisi</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n</span>, <div class=\"year\">1986</div>, <div class=\"source \">Philos. Trans. R. Soc. Series A</div>, <div class=\"volume\">320</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">447</div>\r\n</p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rsta.1986.0128\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1098%2Frsta.1986.0128\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1098%2Frsta.1986.0128\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b59\" data-legacy-id=\"b59\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b59\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b59\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b59\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">van de</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">Ven G.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Falc\u00f3n-Barroso</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">J.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">McDermid</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R. M.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Cappellari</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Miller</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">B. W.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">de Zeeuw</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">P. T.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n</span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">719</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1481</div>\r\n</p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/719/2/1481\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F719%2F2%2F1481\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F719%2F2%2F1481\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b61\" data-legacy-id=\"b61\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b61\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b61\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b61\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">van Dokkum</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">P. G.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n <div class=\"name\">\r\n<div class=\"surname\">Conroy</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">C.</div>\r\n</div>\r\n</span>, <div class=\"year\">2010</div>, <div class=\"source \">Nat</div>, <div class=\"volume\">468</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">940</div>\r\n</p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature09578\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1038%2Fnature09578\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1038%2Fnature09578\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92408906 id=\"92408906\" class=\"backappendixgroup-title\" data-legacy-id=s3>Appendix</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92408907 id=\"92408907\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=ss9>APPENDIX A:\u2002COMPARISON OF LENS MODELS WITH PREVIOUS MODELS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The SWELLS sample contains six spiral lens galaxies that were originally discovered and modelled in SLACS. As a sanity check, we compare the inferred Einstein radii of these lenses from the models presented in this paper with those reported by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2009)</a>. Since <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2009)</a> reported Einstein radii in units of kiloparsecs, we convert our Einstein radii to kiloparsecs also. The comparison is shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. A1</a> and demonstrates agreement between the two sets of models.</p>                        <a id=\"92408909\" scrollto-destination=\"92408909\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=bJrXZ5-xFpfJqdmUnmZh9JG9pS1NiU8QPKp7NKEVP2SyWHwSvxMAvNQsq7tEAzJ5Y3EGy9m7oMf7EgiQB5rCOIcMzlaqsHNwWPlARZFh-aKCgUmeGZ3asL1rPj8qSSEJlxuQHo89jniLFV8yRAodtrN8Nb~BMtigMKFK61CBPwC-g3Wp~r2A5AjEAyHg8hOzSopDW8ZA0xawcVCGV9nhIMrySoR6VHess3KCkv1R~9m--CCHnJASSfKA9PO0Y6FZ7L3B4G50aCd8t8B3dEohhIzCgHy~bZApxFnOx337GKbXdHugMneNVS-PFVXADNq1D6XMg9LZx9RBP0uj41Kieg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A comparison of the inferred Einstein radii of lenses included in the SWELLS sample and the SLACS sample. Error bars were not reported by Auger et al. (2009). The solid line is the one-to-one relation. The inferred Einstein radii are consistent between the two studies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408909/mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408909\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=rj9kIjvRzV0CDzX~oEXNRoajqWzrf8CiH1qIzaHwoe5RXQW5iiuOC83RoBiOe1tjj3Jk8pdSw8gLlWL3v2gPEADTcKZgsSB18kkVtNs6nHe7ml1gPdZ-38Ccv1z6SCq3hsOZQfyoGzi69oHphYGGxNZqi8l8MlHs4LV9DDtqRSc~CHo3nIvPTqF3mVEmav4Uj2korGOoTiU1423pMwpbdMq8fzdaEGCYtcvIB2wjELNMK4QTMb36uYNeUEvPL5gBTE-FwH6OGBIb-JhIbXeQc1OE8yc-RxcXoyUktwFsVtFN3PEc-sVB0twG8~5yTrP-UL7fITdPZAA~RawY~RnrMw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408909&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A comparison of the inferred Einstein radii of lenses included in the SWELLS sample and the SLACS sample. Error bars were not reported by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2009)</a>. The solid line is the one-to-one relation. The inferred Einstein radii are consistent between the two studies.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/m_mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&amp;Signature=bJrXZ5-xFpfJqdmUnmZh9JG9pS1NiU8QPKp7NKEVP2SyWHwSvxMAvNQsq7tEAzJ5Y3EGy9m7oMf7EgiQB5rCOIcMzlaqsHNwWPlARZFh-aKCgUmeGZ3asL1rPj8qSSEJlxuQHo89jniLFV8yRAodtrN8Nb~BMtigMKFK61CBPwC-g3Wp~r2A5AjEAyHg8hOzSopDW8ZA0xawcVCGV9nhIMrySoR6VHess3KCkv1R~9m--CCHnJASSfKA9PO0Y6FZ7L3B4G50aCd8t8B3dEohhIzCgHy~bZApxFnOx337GKbXdHugMneNVS-PFVXADNq1D6XMg9LZx9RBP0uj41Kieg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A comparison of the inferred Einstein radii of lenses included in the SWELLS sample and the SLACS sample. Error bars were not reported by Auger et al. (2009). The solid line is the one-to-one relation. The inferred Einstein radii are consistent between the two studies.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92408909/mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92408909\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/422/4/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x/1/mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg?Expires=1611467854&Signature=rj9kIjvRzV0CDzX~oEXNRoajqWzrf8CiH1qIzaHwoe5RXQW5iiuOC83RoBiOe1tjj3Jk8pdSw8gLlWL3v2gPEADTcKZgsSB18kkVtNs6nHe7ml1gPdZ-38Ccv1z6SCq3hsOZQfyoGzi69oHphYGGxNZqi8l8MlHs4LV9DDtqRSc~CHo3nIvPTqF3mVEmav4Uj2korGOoTiU1423pMwpbdMq8fzdaEGCYtcvIB2wjELNMK4QTMb36uYNeUEvPL5gBTE-FwH6OGBIb-JhIbXeQc1OE8yc-RxcXoyUktwFsVtFN3PEc-sVB0twG8~5yTrP-UL7fITdPZAA~RawY~RnrMw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92408909&ar=1055422&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0422-3574-f8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A comparison of the inferred Einstein radii of lenses included in the SWELLS sample and the SLACS sample. Error bars were not reported by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Auger et al. (2009)</a>. The solid line is the one-to-one relation. The inferred Einstein radii are consistent between the two studies.</p></div></div>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel "Complete", "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": " class=\"chapter-para\">To proceed with the lens galaxy subtractions, we adopted the following procedure. First, for exploratory purposes, we take advantage of the near symmetry of the lens galaxy: by subtracting the image from a 180\u00b0 rotated version of itself, the lensed features, often asymmetric, are revealed (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>). The centre point around which the rotation takes place can be left as a free parameter, and optimized to find the centre of rotation which makes the rotated image best match the original image."}, "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Table correctly loaded": "", "Detection table": "", "Discovery": "3", "Lens Kind": "1", "Warn problem": "About 5 are new detections I cannot isolate from this table."}, "Table map to MasterLens database": {"System Name": "('ID', '(1)')", "RA [\u00b0]": "('RA', '(2)')", "Dec [\u00b0]": "('Dec.', '(3)')", "z_Lens": "('zd', '(4)')@spectroscopic@", "z_Source(s)": "('zs', '(5)')@spectroscopic@", "Einstein_R [\"]": "('b (arcsec)', '(6)')@SIE model@('b (arcsec)', '(6)')", "Stellar velocity disp": "('\u03c3SIE (km\\u2003s\u22121)', '(7)')@@('\u03c3SIE (km\\u2003s\u22121)', '(7)')"}}}, "Table 3": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Table correctly loaded": "", "Detection table": "", "Follow up table": "", "Discovery": "3", "Lens Kind": "1", "Message on table quality": "Not all are new candidates from this paper."}, "Table map to MasterLens database": {"System Name": "('ID', '(1)')", "RA [\u00b0]": "('RA', '(2)')", "Dec [\u00b0]": "('Dec.', '(3)')", "z_Lens": "('zd', '(4)')@spectroscopic@", "z_Source(s)": "('zs', '(5)')@spectroscopic@", "Lens Grade": "('Grade', '(6)')"}}}, "Table 4": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 5": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}, "Table 6": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}}}}, "Tables status": "Complete", "Paper Overview": {"type_of_reference": "JOUR", "Title": "The SWELLS survey - III. Disfavouring 'heavy' initial mass functions for spiral lens galaxies", "authors": ["Brewer, Brendon J.", "Dutton, Aaron A.", "Treu, Tommaso", "Auger, Matthew W.", "Marshall, Philip J.", "Barnab\u00e8, Matteo", "Bolton, Adam S.", "Koo, David C.", "Koopmans, L\u00e9on V. E."], "author_address": ["AA(Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, USA), AB(Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, USA; Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Victoria, Victoria, BC V8P 5C2, Canada; UCO/Lick Observatory, Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, University of California, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, USA), AC(Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, USA), AD(Department of Physics, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, USA; Institute of Astronomy, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA), AE(Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, Stanford University, 452 Lomita Mall, Stanford, CA 94035, USA; Department of Physics, University of Oxford, Keble Road, Oxford OX1 3RH), AF(Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, Stanford University, 452 Lomita Mall, Stanford, CA 94035, USA), AG(Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA), AH(UCO/Lick Observatory, Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, University of California, Santa Cruz, CA 95064, USA), AI(Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen, PO Box 800, 9700 AV Groningen, the Netherlands)"], "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "volume": "422", "publication_year": "2012/06/1", "start_page": "3574", "end_page": "3590", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "stars: luminosity function", "mass function", "galaxies: fundamental parameters", "galaxies: spiral", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2012MNRAS.422.3574B", "abstract": "We present gravitational lens models for 20 strong gravitational lens systems observed as part of the Sloan WFC Edge-on Late-type Lens Survey (SWELLS) project. 15 of the lenses are taken from Paper I, while five are newly discovered systems. The systems are galaxy-galaxy lenses where the foreground deflector has an inclined disc, with a wide range of morphological types, from late-type spiral to lenticular. For each system, we compare the total mass inside the critical curve inferred from gravitational lens modelling to the stellar mass inferred from stellar population synthesis (SPS) models, computing the stellar mass fraction f*\u2261M<SUB>SPS</SUB>/M<SUB>lens</SUB>. We find that, for the lower mass SWELLS systems, adoption of a Salpeter stellar initial mass function (IMF) leads to estimates of f* that exceed 1. This is unphysical and provides strong evidence against the Salpeter IMF being valid for these systems. Taking the lower mass end of the SWELLS sample (\u03c3<SUB>SIE</SUB> &lt; 230 km s<SUP>-1</SUP>), we find that the IMF is lighter (in terms of stellar mass-to-light ratio) than Salpeter with 98 per cent probability, and consistent with the Chabrier IMF and IMFs between the two. This result is consistent with previous studies of spiral galaxies based on independent techniques. In combination with recent studies of massive early-type galaxies that have favoured a heavier Salpeter-like IMF, this result strengthens the evidence against a universal stellar IMF.", "doi": "10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.20870.x", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1201.1677", "issn": "0035-8711", "number": "4"}, "Inspection status": "Incomplete"}
